I have just got back from seeing this film and I am so glad we chose it today. I couldn't fault the acting, but the only thing I would say is please do not take a young child to see this. Its so upsetting even for an adult. Personally I would say no child under 12 should see it. The only other film where everyone sat quiet and still until the credits had finished, was Schindler's List. I was speechless afterwards and I am someone that has known about the holocaust all my life as I was born just after the war finished, but every time I see something like this, I find myself just not being able to fathom out how human beings could treat others in this way. I could see what was going to happen (re: the ending) and most people I imagine would, but it didn't make it any less terrifying. OK, this was fiction but it was easy to see how this could easily have happened for real. This happened in a civilised country. I am afraid that I can never, ever forgive what these people did - to me, its almost in my lifetime and certainly in my sister's and my parents of course. Of course these films should be shown, but the only thing I would say is that they do rake up old memories and make it difficult to forgive or move on. I know most of the perpetrators will be dead now, but nonetheless, we tend to tar a nation with the same brush. I work with 2 German ladies and have to face them at work tomorrow - I will find it hard to do.

reviews.review_title: The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas
reviews.content: From director Mark Herman (Brassed Off, Little Voice), I had heard a few bits and pieces about this film, and it sounded like something I might like. Set in World War II, the story sees eight-year-old Bruno (Asa Butterfield) moving house with sister Gretel (Amber Beattie) and Mother (Vera Farmiga), because of his Nazi-officer Father (Harry Potter's David Thewlis) being promoted. They have relocated to the countryside of Germany, where the Father, unknown to Bruno, is the commanding officer of a near prison camp. A mysterious man dressed in what seem to be striped pyjamas, named Pavel (David Hayman), who is actually a Jewish prisoner (and ex-doctor), talks to Bruno a little. But Bruno is curious of the "farm" he can see from his window, and disobeying his Mother, he explores what unknown to him is a concentration camp, and he forms a friendship with eight-year-old Schultz (Béla Fesztbaum), also dressed in striped pyjamas, like many others behind the electrified bard-wire fence. Both being young and naive, they don't realise the reality of the situation, with Shmultz and many others in the camp being Jewish and seen by the Nazis as an enemy. In the end, Bruno dresses in some pyjamas, and he and Schultz attempt to find his missing Father, and when Bruno's family realise where he may have gone to, by the time they get there, he, Scmultz and many other Jews have been exterminated. Also starring Richard Johnson as Grandpa, Sheila Hancock as Grandma, Rupert Friend as Lieutenant Kotler and Jim Norton as Herr Liszt. It is heartbreaking to see the children befriending each other without knowing the truth about what is going on, and you really realise the tragedy and cruelty of events that occurred back then. Good!

reviews.review_title: Emotionally draining, if at times overly simplistic
reviews.content: A classic "through the eyes of childhood" story about the Holocaust. Asa Butterfield plays Bruno, a German 8 year-old whose father (David Thewlis) is the officer in charge of a concentration camp. Bruno has no clue what goes on at the camp, which he initially thinks is a farm where the weird farmers wear pajamas all the time. He sneaks up to the fence outside of the camp and meets a Jewish boy, whom he befriends. Slowly, he comes to realize that something awful is happening, and that his father is partly responsible for it. It's a great concept. It's not a great movie. I'm unsure if the fault lies with the original novel or the screenplay (by director Herman, best known for a couple of '90s indies, Little Voice and Brassed Off), but the story eschews interesting moral philosophy in favor of a more base emotionality. This is especially true in the ridiculously forced climactic sequence, with its swelling music and completely illogical cross-cutting. There's an earlier sequence in which Bruno informs on the Jewish boy in order to get out of some trouble. This should have formed the climax, similar to Louis Malle's Au Revoir les Enfants. It's impossible to deny that The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is powerful, but it should have been better.

The story revolves around two boys, one a German, the other a Jew. They live on opposites sides of a dire fence. They share a bond humanity has forgotten.I don't want to write about the movie. The plot is self-explanatory. We are all familiar with the brutality of the concentration camps of World War II. This story depicts that brutality with a sincere sense of sentimentality and severity, in a no-holds-barred manner. The ending is unforgettable. I can only say that I bought the movie right after seeing it for the first time, and I put it on the shelf in my top-ten section. I watch it every several months.Have tissues handy. This movie dropped my head in my hands.

reviews.review_title: I like this movie, but you might not
reviews.content: This movie contains some emotional things, maybe you would find hyperbole. Because of you can feel who produce use your feel about a kid at the end of film, like I feel. But generally theme was good. Yes, we know there are many 2nd war scenarios and sometimes they are copy of each of them. But this movie wasn't without end. It has extremely original story. Yes I didn't like end, but it is best appropriate end for this movie. Because story has to be end stunning as possible as.

reviews.review_title: Absolute Gut wrenching. Heart warming tale of friendship and horrors
reviews.content: Having studied about WW2 and the German atrocities, seeing such a movie made me cry despite knowing how inhumane people can be.What started off as a sweet and innocent movie couldnt have had any other ending to drive home the horrors that subjected more than 6 million people.My heart still breaks when I read about the current world scenario and the rise of extremism which is basically a rehash of the Nazis. Apparently, people are stupid not to learn from history.

I'm not sure who this film is for. Young people watching it will get precisely the wrong idea. Adults watching it will see a very silly representation of what would have been an extremely harrowing story if it was true. This production is very poor. I'm inclined to think that the presentation had the same treatment window dressers would give to a winter festival themed department store's windows. There are numerous continuity errors - it's a bit like an edition of 'Crossroads' except the props are not cardboard. At least it's only 94 minutes long - it'll be over before you've realised and it won't stick in your mind for long.

reviews.review_title: A new film about the Holocaust
reviews.content: This film is not like any other film about the Holocaust. It is through the eyes of children. Children who do not see racism or hate. Most of us have seen it and know about it. We know that millions of people were killed. As adults or teenagers we know. We've seen movies or have learned about the atrocities that occurred. This film tells us the story of two children on both sides of the Holocaust.Bruno is the 8 year old son of the Commander of the Auschwitz Death Camp when it is still in development. He begins a friendship with another 8 year old boy who is a prisoner in a newly established, lightly defended part of the massive camp. What follows is an emotional story told through the innocent eyes of the two kids telling it.This film strikes an emotion never brought on before by a film about the Holocaust. It isolates young children as the primary storyteller, through the childlike view of what is happening in their individual worlds. The conclusion is shown through three different characters: the view of the two children, the actions and reactions of the adults, and the view of the audience. Each may have a different reaction.

Having anticipated an amazing film after hearing such excellent reviews, I hate to say that I was incredibly disappointed. I felt from the start that the film lacked that authentic feel that other Holocaust film like 'Schindler's list' had. This was probably due to the fact that 'The Boy in The Striped Pyjamas' was set in Germany but all the characters, including the Jewish boy and all the soldiers had ridiculously British upper class accents. Even a bad German accent would have been better! Also, Bruno, who was the son of a soldier, had been brought up in Berlin in Nazi Germany but yet the audience are supposed to believe that Bruno had no previous understanding of the situation whatsoever, which is completely unrealistic, since by the time concentration camps were in use, practically every school in Germany would have drummed in to the children that "Jews were responsible for all the problems". Furthermore, the boy that Bruno befriends (a Jew working in the concentration camp) manages, with no problems from the guards, to regularly meet Bruno, play board games and eat food which he passes through the fence. I just found the whole thing incredibly hard to believe. The only way that this story would be at all plausible is if the Jewish boy was simply an imaginary friend, created by Bruno to replace those he lost after leaving Berlin. Bruno is always portrayed as being an explorer, is it possibly that his curiosity alone lead him to enter the concentration camp? Who knows...but for me, imaginary friend or not, unfortunately this film was just not as realistic or engaging as I had hoped.

I mean that the movie was stunning in the sense that this film will absolutely stun you emotionally. It portrays the holocaust through the eyes of an innocent child. It was so captivating that you will feel like you are there seeing, smelling, and hearing all that the characters are sensing. The writing is powerful, and the acting is superb. The suspense is so subtly brought forth that you don't see it coming in that you don't realize that the entire film is one big suspenseful build up to the end. Overall, this film is incredibly well done. The message about the horrors of the holocaust will stay with you, as the film is hauntingly memorable.

reviews.review_title: I bet this movie will stay with you for a long long time
reviews.content: Even though this movie was suggested to me by my friend in 2009, I ended up watching it in 2019. Oh boy, what was I waiting for. This story revolves around the 8 year kid called Bruno who is instinctively an explorer and he depicts it (in nazi Germany). A set of events lead the family of this boy to leave their city Berlin and move to a far away country side of Germany . This journey gives you clues that the place is in some sense haunting (won't reveal any more ). Bruno continues with his pursuit of adventure over there through which he finds a 8 year old Friend . The climax is for you to see . This movie is not as much about the Holocaust but about human emotions, about the innocence of children ,why the grace and good nature of women is taking care of this world , the monster in every men and how life can be a Frankenstein . This movie will stay with you for a long time , will anguish you , will hearten you and will make u ponder .Must watch . Go with 4.5/5 . PS: I would suggest that you watch Schindler's list and pianist before watching this . Will help you appreciate this movie better

reviews.review_title: One of the best film about genocide
reviews.content: The film is very good, excited and sad. Actors play their role very well.

reviews.review_title: One Of the Best Movies I've Seen
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas has got to be one of the most amazing movies i've ever seen.Before seeing the movie I read the book, which I really enjoyed and found very touching and eye opening. I was a little nervous to see the movie as I was afraid that it might not live up to the standards I had after reading the book. But I was not disappointed at all. The movie stayed with the book very well. Of course it wasn't exactly the same but it was very close.I was very impressed with the cast selection. I enjoyed the fact that non of the actors were well known, it somehow made the acting more believable. I also noticed that the actors looked as I imagined them while I was reading the book.The thing I was most impressed with was the acting itself. It was so convincing and realistic it was as if these things were really happening to these actors.The only critique I have for the movie was the accents the characters used, It was much more of an English accent than a German one. I am German and speak some and have many friends with German accents and I'm afraid that the accents in this movie are not anywhere near what I recognize to be a German accent.Overall I was VERY happy with the movie and can't wait to watch it again. 9/10 !

reviews.review_title: Although contains most of the plot, not as good as the book!
reviews.content: I believe that although the film contains most of the plot that one might expect it to contain, it does not do what the book sets out to do! When i was reading the book i found it to be a masterpiece of literature that all should read. The film, however, doe not follow the accuracies of the book, for example in the book the woods can be seen out of the window in Gretels room and the fence runs along from Bruno's room. in the film however Bruno has to walk through the woods to get to the fence! These are coupled with other mistakes, i would suggest that one should read either the book or watch the film, otherwise one will likely get annoyed with the opposite of what they are writing!

I cannot recommend this movie enough. It isn't going to be an upbeat, feel good movie, but it is certainly one worth watching. I can't even describe in words how wonderful this film is, but wow... it left me feeling things for weeks after watching it for the first time.

reviews.review_title: A touching film, deeply moving and will stick in your mind for a while. Oh, and it should make you cry.
reviews.content: A touching film, deeply moving and will stick in your mind for a while. Oh, and it should make you cry. This is a film about two boys who become friends in unusual circumstances. One boy is in a concentration camp and the other whose father is a member of the German army and leader of the concentration camp become friends in the most unlikeable of circumstances.This, as films go, is not a feel good movie. Yes there are bits in it that may bring a smile to your face, but no, overall the film is a harsh kick in the pants of the sort of atrocities that happened during WWII. To diagnose this film is rather difficult because it does have two lights on it, the beautiful innocence and friendship of two lonely boy's friendship and yet it is still clouded in dark due to the story that we know is basically unfolding.Overall a great film, sad as I have said, but I highly recommend seeing it! If you do manage to get the opportunity to watch this film, I suggest doing it with someone who you don't mind cuddling or at least crying with. I reckon this film will bring all parents to tears and I dare to say some of the "tougher" men too.On what seems to be a lower budget (US$12,500,000) than most of Hollywoods releases. This film does really well for it. Unfortunately most Australians will have to wait till 23rd April '09 to see this film, but when you get the chance don't let it slip past.

reviews.review_title: Very powerful - but not quite how I pictured it
reviews.content: I saw this film at home shortly after completing the book, so obviously the plot and minor details were all still fresh in my mind. And I have to say that while I did find the film very moving, there were a few glaring things I noticed that didn't seem to match with the book. I'll just get those out of the way first; 1) The characters look quite different to how I pictured them. Bruno in particular looks like a mini-Hitler, with the perfect haircut and big blue eyes which he doesn't seem to blink. I expected his father to have a big curly moustache, not that that matters! ;) 2) The friendship between Bruno and Shmuel didn't interest me in the film as it had done in the book. Bruno actually regards Shmuel with disdain at first, and doesn't seem to like his name much. 3) Smhuel actually looks about the same size as Bruno, and a lot of the people in the camp at the end look rather well-fed. I found I was able to watch them without feeling too distressed, as they didn't look particularly unhealthy - just dirty and forlorn. 4) The meeting point for the two boys was set in a forest, and not too far away from Bruno's house. It is a walk of a couple of miles in the book, and I expected it to be more open, barren. Shmuel is actually within sight of the soldiers and fellow camp mates, and yet they happily play Chess and throw balls to one another over the fence. 5) Bruno not only already has a pair of striped pyjamas, but he also doesn't shave his hair! And he takes his cap off before entering the gas chamber, yet no-one notices him!However, these points aside, there were some excellent parts which I - well, not enjoyed, but was deeply moved by. 1) When Kotler lost his temper with Pavel, the looks on the faces of the children really broke my heart. I couldn't believe the father was sitting there eating calmly, while his family were almost in tears! 2) The mother gave an outstanding performance - I could really feel her distress when searching for Bruno, and when Kotler accidentally revealed the source of the 'awful smell', I joined her in horrified shock, she conveyed her emotion so well. 3) Aside from his Nazi-ish looks (and the rather shaky start to the friendship), I thought Bruno did a wonderful job too. At the end, as he was comforting Smhuel in the 'shower', I was willing them to escape, to survive - and of course his childish innocence was well delivered. 4) Gretel did a good job of playing the bratty but there-when-you-need-her sister, and the scene with her sitting in bed with Bruno as their parents argued was very moving. 5) Of course, the final, dramatic scene with the gas chamber - all the banging and panic, and then just silence. Words can't describe how incredible that scene was. It was just so awful... All in all, if I hadn't read the book previously, I would've given this about a 9, but there were just a few parts here and there that I was uncomfortable with. The cast delivered excellent performances however, and I would definitely watch this again.

Just one of the holocaust stories told in the way that is base for stereotypes today, I believe: kids that are building the bridges of hope on the river of death where no hope exists. Slow and predictable, from time to time irritating for the reason of childish logic presented. The kind of logic that better matches director's thinking than thoughts of the little boy. Without very good camera and good acting, this film would look like average low budget attempt to make a TV movie. In return, I will present childish logic too and give a movie rate number 4, higher than it really deserves only because I like Vera Farmiga very much.

reviews.review_title: One of the most heartbreaking films I've seen
reviews.content: Words cannot describe how I feel about this film; only that it truly was a masterpiece. I went to see it with my mum, expecting the "telltale ending" of the film - the film is about a young German boy who befriends a young Jewish boy imprisoned in a concentration camp. Having been to Terezin Concentration Camp near Prague and having learnt about the Final Solution in GCSE History, I had a background knowledge of the film's theme.When the film was finished, the whole of the audience sat in complete silence, save for a few people (including my mum and myself) in tears. The film was moving, and the message is one that I shall stick by; friendship and love can be found in the most darkest of times.The musical score was also fantastic - James Horner is a genius.I HIGHLY recommend the film, but I must insist (by not revealing much) that you should keep a box of tissues handy.

"The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a very touching film about the story of friendship between two boys representing the species of two different races. One is German, the other is Jewish. The film shows us another ruthlessness of politics, in fact, as in all times. After all, this topic is relevant even today. In principle, the Holocaust is a very important part of history and many films have been made on this topic, but it is "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" that stands out from the rest of the films. And this is not a movie with a happy ending. It was extremely sorry for the boy and his father at the end. And most of all, it is sad from the misunderstanding on the part of the German boy, since he did not understand why he was forbidden to communicate, in fact, with the same child as he was. During the entire film, we can observe a sincere, childhood friendship that has no boundaries, no rules, as in adulthood. From this film, I received a maximum of warm emotions from the relationship of the kids, and also felt very sad.

The setting for this movie is Europe during WWII. A German officer who commands a nearby camp for Jewish prisoners lives with his family on the fringe of the camp. The story is through the eyes of the young son of the German Officer. Surprisingly, I found this movie had a fresh take on a WWII setting that so many movies before have taken. Keeping true to the novel, this movie does what so few movies can do well - Give you an Exceptionally Moving Experience Emotionally. You feel as if you have experienced the War through the young boys eyes.You will be left speechless by the end of this movie. I can only recommend you watch this movie, as few words can adequately describe how you will feel upon completion of this movie. I would recommend everyone in high school to watch this movie, and would suggest parents to watch this with middle school children. It is a powerfully emotional movie and will raise some questions in your children. If anything good comes of it, they will feel the shame as a human and the heartache resulting from wars running wild.

reviews.review_title: It's ok but IMO not the best.
reviews.content:
I agree that this is an utterly devastating movie. Not much happens and it is a bit on the quiet side but it does make you feel.While the ending is something that made me feel numb for quite awhile afterwards, I couldn't help but keep thinking that most people would come away from this feeling for the main character, whereas I just felt sad for the boy through the fence. The moment when they are inside and the main boy says he doesn't know the other just made me dislike the main character. The main boys dad was not a nice man so I didn't feel sorry in the slightest and actually found myself thinking "ha!" for him at the end of the movie. Not everyone will be like that though, I know, I can be heartless!I wished something happened to the young soldier too, he was a a-hole!
To me, there are better movies and mini series to portray WWII.Sorry for saying boy a lot, I forget the characters names!

My acquaintance with this story began with reading the book. It's not very big, but there's something about it. Something that is difficult to describe, but it is impossible to stop thinking about.The film did not disappoint me. Like the book, it is built on feelings, light, but at the same time heavy. It is undoubtedly about the war, but about the war shown through the eyes of a boy who has never seen evil in his life. The main thing is what the film takes for the soul (as well as the book) this is the naivety of the main character. Bruno does not divide people, as does his father, his sister; his world is full of amazing discoveries and adventures.Little Shmuel's life is completely different. But he is not broken. He's in a cage, his family is being tortured by soldiers, but he's stronger than them. Because he has faith, simple childish faith. The end is unspeakably terrible, but not even because what is happening is happening, but because you look into Bruno's eyes, you seem to be among these people, his calm compresses your heart, you want to scream: Run! Only there's nowhere to run. That's what it is. This is a dead end. Cruelty is a dead end.Dad, who are these people in striped pajamas?Bruno, they are not people at all.To be remembered.10 out of 10.

As a Holocaust scholar I found this movie to be terribly inaccurate and a cheap ploy to wring emotions from the crowd. I was truly disappointed by this film which promised to offer a new insight into the events of the Holocaust by seeing it through the eyes of a child. Instead the film felt like a lame B-Movie trying to make the audience jump and squirm and cry without actually drawing them into a story with any substance. I spent so much time watching the screen intently looking for meaning I wound up with a headache, and I have never heard so many angry mutterings after a film ended as I did in that theater. Please do not waste your time on this film, if you wish to see an accurate and actually moving portrayal of the Holocaust, see "Schindler's List," "Holocaust," "Uprising," or "The Grey Zone."

reviews.review_title: "A story of innocence in a world of ignorance"
reviews.content:
Through the innocent eyes of Bruno, the eight-year-old son of the commandant at a German concentration camp, a forbidden friendship with a Jewish boy on the other side of the camp fence has startling and unexpected consequences. (Source: IMDb)The Boy in the striped pyjamas is "A story of innocence in a world of ignorance" and one of the most emotional movies I have ever seen, although I think it was a bit boring and not quite the best but I do recommend everyone to see it, great story and emotional ending.The movie could have been a really great movie especially that it's based on a book by John Boyne that's so famous and so emotional, so they had a great story but I felt like the script was so weak and the way that the movie was telling the story wasn't what I expected, I also felt like it could have won "Best adapted screenplay" if the script was so good which is going to take me to the directing too that was good but not great, felt like the movie could have had so many great and memorable frames which it did but they were very few.The cast was good although I felt like some actors and actresses would have fit the role better, Asa Butterfield as Bruno was a great choice, he always puts on a great performance although he was young. Jack Scanlon was so amazing in playing the role of Shmuel, you can feel the chemistry between the two young actors which I think what made the movie so great, David Thewlis as Commander Ralf and Rupert Friend as Lieutenant Kotler were so amazing they both gave us these dirty and evil characters that you will hate after watching the movie, and Finally, Vera Farmiga as Elsa who I felt like in some scenes she was trying so hard to just fit into that character but could not, the only scene I liked was when she was fighting with her husband Commander Ralf, but other than that her facial expressions and acting were not that great.The music score was not a problem at all, it added a great touch to a few scenes and it even made some scenes more emotional.The movie showed us what life was during "The Holocaust" in such a genuine, dramatic, and emotional way because "The Holocaust" is a difficult subject for sure that many people suffered during it.
Highly recommend this emotional / sad movie that will touch your heart and will leave you in tears after watching it.My rating is 7/10

This film is truly haunting. Though it is based on fictitious characters, that does not in any way diminish the profound emotions one experiences during this film. There is such an incredible sense of frailty in the film, and one cannot help but be consumed by the reality of the experience. Asa Butterfield's performance is so incredibly perfect that one forgets they are watching a film. There is a sense of innocence in his performance that lends itself beautifully to the utter despair one feels while experiencing this film for the first time. Bruno truly encompasses all the innocence and humanity that was lost during the Holocaust. In turn, this film begs us to remember that while compassion was lost for many, the beauty of friendship can never be destroyed.

Contains spoiler. I took my 10 year old son to see this.I thought it would be a film about friendship arising in bizarre situations more than anything else, and with a happy ending.The promo poster, with the 2 boys sitting near each other under an attractive colourful sky is quite deceiving, too. The ending, which happens very quickly was a real shock to me, because I understood it. My son, however, didn't understand it, as, to him, it was just a bunch of naked people going into a shower. When the credits started rolling, he said he didn't understand it. I was really quite choked up. It is a brilliant film. Of coarse, the cinema was dead silent for a couple of minutes. So I told him I'd explain it a bit later, which I did when we left. I wasn't quite prepared to tell him about the Holocaust, (I don't believe a 10 year old should know of the appalling things that have happened),and I don't think he really understood it afterwards. At the Imperial War Museums' permanent Holocaust exhibition, they do not let children younger than 14 in. I believe this is more appropriate. How can a child understand this subject matter? So I think it should have been given a 15 certificate, at least. As I said, the film is great. The German characters speaking English was a good idea. It made them appear more like people we may know. More like "normal" people, which, of coarse they were. Anyone can be brainwashed. The German population had it all through the 30s. Can any one person among us say they would have been immune to it? The music score, usually so overpowering and overdone in most modern films, was very subtle. There was one scene with a very effective contrast, during the first encounter of the 2 boys, the very healthy looking German on the one side of the barbed wire (which wasn't shown during his shot), with the green trees and blue sky behind him,all very peaceful, then the shot of the Jewish boy (dirty, missing teeth, shaved head, wire in shot),with concrete and dirt around him, and people shouting in the distance.The film also succeeded in keeping EVERYONES' attention the whole way through, a rare thing, and the way nobody spoke at the end, was uncanny. I've never been to the cinema and witnessed that before.

reviews.review_title: I regretted that I did not watch this at the movies
reviews.content: I have never read the novel and sadly I never knew this film exist before last year when someone mentioned her intention to watch the film. This is a film that will make your chest tighten and make your eyes wet. I have watched several films with WWII background and this is the first film that provides a point of view of a young kid, which is very rare despite the fact that children feel the damages as well. The ending is unbelievably surprising for me, I wasn't expecting it. I must control myself so I wouldn't bleed my own palms with my nails as the film reaching its end. All in all, it is worth watching and definitely one of the best films I ever watched.

reviews.review_title: we like this movie because we like who we are
reviews.content: okay we see this movie and everything that we suspect that will happen, does actually happen. so why do we love this picture? why do we give this picture so many points? let me begin with the ending. the movie ends the way it does, because otherwise there would be no message. we all know the message from the beginning of the picture, however, and we can tell how the picture is going to end, because we know the rules of Hollywood. we know Hollywood loves making films with a moralistic message. in this movie, that message, the lesson we can learn from all we witness, is way too obvious. so why do we still love this kind of picture? that's not so difficult. we love this kind of picture, because it shows us what we suspect to see, what we want to see. it actually learns us the moral we already know and we like that because by that the movie gives us the feeling we are watching a memory of ourself, something we already know. because we already know what we will see (even if we haven't seen it yet and even if the climax may be shocking for us), we get an approval of ourself. because we like who we are (well, the most of us do), we like this movie.and that's all there is. this movie isn't a good movie, it's all an illusion. we are watching ourself on the screen and we are hypocrites enough to believe we haven't seen this before and everything is alright. even if we leave the cinema with a feeling of 'good it's just a movie' we are telling ourselves a lie.this movie is one big lie, there are many faults in it, I guess almost 24. I know it's not easy to understand (because of the so called difference in time), but this movie shows us a mirror. we like this movie because we like who we are.

This film is a story of two boys Bruno and Schmuel. Bruno is son of a German commander, while Schmuel is a Jewish boy in a concentration camp which is located near where Bruno has come to live. Bruno doesn't know anything about the concentration camp, while he thinks that it is a farm and farmers wear pajamas. The first time he meets Schmuel, he asks while do you wear such clothes.Many films about Holocaust are made, but this film still is able to look different from the rest. The entire story is seen from the eyes of a young 8 year old boy, who asks his fascist tutor if there is not a single jew, and the tutor replies if Bruno could find even one good jew, he would be the greatest explorer.Bruno's grandmother disapproves what her son that is Bruno's dad does, while Bruno's grandfather is also a fascist. Bruno's mother (Vera Farmiga) doesn't want her kids to live near a concentration camp. But Bruno's father is adamant. There are some breathtaking scenes in the film, especially when Bruno asks his father what is being burnt in those chimneys? Really, this is a very cruel reality of which Bruno is completely unaware of, and may not be able to fathom even if he is told.Bruno's sister Greta, a 12 year old, is also fond of Hitler, and may become a fascist in the future. This story is about the friendship of two naive 8 year old German and Jewish boys. Bruno's domestic help Pavel, a Jew is a doctor, but still their servant. Bruno thinks he must not be a good doctor, so now he peels potatoes. Schmuel also doesn't know what is done in the camp'.The most impressive aspect about the film is the dialogue between the two boys, who are completely unaware of the ghastly things going around.You do get very much idea about what is going to happen in the end, but the film in the climax will still shock you and keep you stunned for a while.
Added in my most favourite movie list. This is Perfect and beautiful Cinema. Love the direction, editing, acting,art, Cinematography everything is on point
SAD STORY;) I LIKE IT...MY FAVOURITE MOVIE IN 2021 🤗😇

I knew this Movie would be shocking as it was set during the holocaust but i definitely didn't prepare myself for this film. I won't say any more as it would spoil it for everyone willing to watch it.The movie is fantastically scripted and acted. In my opinion the actors did a wonderful job, especially Bruno (Asa Butterfield)as you see the movie unfold through his eyes. He plays his part with such innocence and is not entirely sure what's going on at first, he is very confused about his Fathers area of work. His father (David Thewlis) plays the part of the Father wonderfully. You can tell he cares very deeply for his family but also has great pride in his job and comes off as a cold emotionless character. The Mother (Vera Farmiga) is very much different from her husband as we can see her character crumbling when she discovers the grim truth about her husbands work. You can really put yourself in the picture and feel how disturbing it would have been to be a part of the holocaust. At first we would think that Shmuel (Jack Scanlon) is the Boy in the striped Pyjamas,as we see him and Bruno form a friendship even though they are divided by the barbed wire. but as the devastating ending draws near we realise it is indeed Bruno. As we go through the film seeing the holocaust through Bruno's eyes it makes us realise that we are all innocent human beings, just like Bruno and Shmuel who are very different people but are supposed to be enemies separated by the fence. It is only when we are Adults that we have our own beliefs and take in life that we are no longer as innocent and can become 'monsters' The adaptation of 'the boy in the striped pyjamas makes us realise that many people were separated during the holocaust, not by a barbed wire but by ignorance and we forget what a cruel time this was. The film can be upsetting and shocking but is also not one to miss. I would definitely give 'the boy in the striped pyjamas' 10 stars, and recommend it to everyone!I also wouldn't recommend letting young children see this film. Im 18 and was disturbed by it. I think they should greatly consider raising the certificate to a 15.

I am completely devastated, this is such an incredibly moving film. This truly is the film of the year. INCREDIBLE performances from all the actors, but especially Asa Butterfield (Bruno), Vera Farmiga (Mother) and Jack Scanlon (Schmuel). The whole film is extremely realistic and that adds to the intense impact of this film.The story line and the characters are believable and they are an effective way to tell of life during Hitler's reign.This story is moving and the end is tragic. I am normally one to blubber at all films, but this film moved me so much i could not even cry, all i could do was shake in despair as i watched it happen on screen, i felt helpless just like many people living during that time period must have. Afterwards when the credits started rolling, everyone sat there staring at the screen and even when walking out, not a word was spoken. The atmosphere was a real indication of the effect of which the film had on every single person in that cinema.I really would recommend this film to anyone, but it will affect you for a long time afterwards. I took GCSE Modern World History, and nothing could have prepared me for the reality shock which this film has shown me. A real eye opener, i think that both John Boyne (who wrote the novel) and Mark Herman (Screenplay) have done themselves proud, a sensitive topic which they have delicately (and successfully) handled. A potential Oscar winner. Just sensational.

First of all I would like to mention the best about this movie.It is indeed a very good looking film. The cinematography and the costumes are absolutely amazing and very close to the atmosphere of the decade that the movie takes place. Also Vera Farmiga gives and amazing performance. She is by far the best this movie has to offer. Also good (of course) was David Thewlis but here is the first big BUT about "The boy in the striped Pyjamas"...The British accent of Thewlis and not only ruined a very big amount of the film cause felt so out of place! I understand that this was a BBC production, but again! Thewlis playing a Nazi was way Britisher than it was acceptable!My last BIG bad point about the movie is the music! The score is absolutely out of the spirit! In the first scene with the same happy tune that it presented the German Kids go over to the poor Jewis... and in the closing scene, Jesus! Nothing emotional in a very good scene!that's all for me!!

reviews.review_title: You can't better a good book!
reviews.content: The subject of WW2 always seems to work. The bad and evil Germans against the world! Add the innocence of kids into the equation and you should be able to come up with a decent enough story. The book was indeed very enjoyable. The movie not so much.The look and feel is pretty lame. Everything is far too neat, from the costumes, to the decorations, and the dialogs. It feels as though the characters are robots and stripped of any human traits. No, it has got nothing to do with portraying the Nazis! the kids are just as lame! To keep it short, i'd say: if you have read the book, do not bother watching this. If you haven't, you may enjoy it as it's a fresh approach to the Nazis subject...

The film is portrayed though young Bruno (Asa Butterfield) who is unknowingly caught in the midst of the holocaust and after relocating due to his father's (David Thewlis) promotion befriends Shmuel (Jack Scanlon). I refuse to reveal any more as this is a must see movie.I watched it on DVD and was bummed I wasn't able to watch it in theaters on the big screens but either way it was fulfilling enough. Every aspect of the film puzzles in together to guarantee you will not be disappointed in any way. Not only does this film make tears roll out of every pair of eyes watching, it intently captivates and keeps them mesmerized as well. From the portrayal of the characters to the storyline to the breathtaking finale this movie was absolutely amazing.P.S. Just wanted to add that Asa Butterfield was magnificent along with David Thewlis, Vera Farmiga and Jack Scanlon. This movie was excellent form start to finish.

This week, I sat through 3 films centred on the Nazis and Jews during WWII - "The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas", "Defiance" and "Good". Of the 3, this is by far the superior movie. "Good" just wasn't very good. "Defiance" suffered from being overlong, of dubious historical accuracy, and from a typical Edward Zwick Boys' Own Adventure ending, a throwback to the old Cowboys and Indians battles with the cavalry riding to the rescue."The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas", on the other hand, contained a gut-wrenching, powerful ending. The film provided insight into the psychology of Nazi concentration camp commanders. To Bruno's Dad, the Jews are "not really people" (in "Good", they're called "items"). Like a factory manager, he pores over plans to expand the gas chambers and "triple the throughput". I've read of Nazis at the train stations, separating families, tearing children from their parents, regarding the beings under their control as simply animals.It's a typical protective psychological response, apparently. Battles in the Pacific were more vicious and caused proportionately greater casualties, because the Americans and Japanese each convinced themselves that their enemy was some kind of sub-human species and should be obliterated from the face of the earth.Executioners and abattoir slaughtermen use the same mechanism, concentrating on the process of disposal, upon the technicalities of the job, rather than on the fact of the living being that they are dealing with, who will soon no longer be living.Only at the end does the horror and suffering and inhumanity of the gas chambers strike home to Bruno's father. The film's been criticised for not tying up all the loose ends, but I think it's irrelevant. Will the Dad strike out at the Jews in revenge? Will he throw over the job and end up in a shallow grave with the rest of his family? It doesn't matter. The film's point has been made, extremely well in my opinion. The ease with which the kids can conduct their relationship may stretch the bounds of credibility, but the basic premise is a good one, and the acting is terrific. An 8/10.

reviews.review_title: Not a very good film. I was really disappointed with this.
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas. Where to start. In the first few minutes you will notice the bad acting on the roles of the Germans. They do not act like Germans, the feeling just doesn't come across... At all. It seems more like a bunch of Brits with Nazi costumes on, exactly what it is. Once we get past the bad acting, you'll notice that the storyline is utterly ridiculous. It's awful how the Holocaust is still being used as this money machine for film makers, and this movie in particular was a shameful failure. The weak attempt of getting emotion from the audience at the end was really disappointing (However it apparently worked for some).This movie needed a fat dose of heartfelt drama and emotion, but even then i don't think it would ever get away with the over-coincidental ending that will leave many thinking "Are you kidding me?". I can't imagine that this film would trigger much of an emotional response from people capable of any sort of independent thought and reason and critical analysis. People who leech from the notorious holocaust vein make films which are generally so "old" and rehashed. If they have the nerve to do it, they ought to at least make something half decent and worth watching. The million dollar movie concoction: Holocaust, Jews, furnaces, magical showers.Overall, The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is a film that was lacking. It lacked in substance, in plot, and most importantly, in authenticity. I don't really recommend it.

reviews.review_title: Perhaps a little misjudged, but ultimately an effective anti-war tale.
reviews.content: 'The Boy In The Striped Pajamas (2008)' focuses on a young German boy who, during WWII, moves out to the country with his family so that his Nazi father can oversee operations at a nearby concentration camp. The picture focuses on putting its audience in the perspective of its naïve protagonist, typically presenting its atrocities in an implicit yet still impactful way. In some regards, it seems a little watered down but that's actually because the boy we're following isn't exposed to the true horrors around him and doesn't really understand those he does actually see. We do, though, and the piece isn't afraid to pull its punches in that regard. The young boy soon makes friends with a Jewish boy inside the camp, visiting him for daily chats through the fence. This is one of the primary focuses of the flick, a friendship that crosses the arbitrary boundaries put in place by the Nazi regime and flies in the face of the hate that Hitler tried to force onto every German citizen, regardless of their true feelings. The film is a little bit problematic because it focuses on a German family, with its Jewish characters - even the eponymous boy in the striped pajamas - being largely relegated to the background. It's also dodgy that the movie's great tragedy (spoilers, by the way) is that one German boy dies in a camp that he shouldn't be in. The reality is, of course, that nobody should be in there, and the tragedy of the millions of deaths of the people deemed 'subhuman' by the Nazis should really be the tragedy - as it was in real life. However, the film is trying to convey the fact that war affects everyone; the children being brainwashed into hating others are victims, too. The affair isn't trying to be desensitise or take focus away from the real atrocities it's based around. Even though it isn't always successful and may be a little misjudged, I don't think it has ill intentions. In fact, it's trying to do an admirable thing. I can see where its criticisms come from, but I don't believe it to be a harmful piece of media. It's a generally effective anti-war story. 7/10.

Reaching carefully through the barbed wire fence that separates them, two eight-year-old boys shake hands. It is a sign of forgiveness and reassurance that they are still friends, but there are no smiles here, for more than just a fence separates Bruno and Shmuel. Bruno is the son of a Nazi commandant, while Shmuel is a Jewish prisoner in a concentration camp close to Bruno's new home. It is the ultimate forbidden friendship and one of the many clichés that riddle The Boy in the Striped Pajamas and make it less of a historical film than a parable about the dangers and devastating consequences of inhumanity and immorality.As the film opens, Bruno (Asa Butterfield) and his affluent family prepare to move from their old estate in Berlin to their new home in the countryside, which they have acquired because of Bruno's father's promotion. Bruno's father, Ralf (David Thewlis), is the conventional Nazi soldier: harsh, brutal, and uncompromising. His wife, Elsa (Vera Farmiga), is his antithesis and a stereotypical, meek, emotional, and ignorant woman. Tension develops in their marriage when they move to their new home, nearby a concentration camp, because Elsa is concerned about their proximity to the death camp and objects to Ralf's "evil" work.Bruno eventually finds his way to this concentration camp, which he believes is a farm, one day when he is exploring, his favorite hobby. There, he meets a boy his own age, Shmuel (Jack Scanlon). Though Bruno thinks Shmuel is a strange farmer who wears striped pajamas, they quickly befriend each other, for both of them are lonely. When Shmuel tells Bruno that he is a Jew, Bruno decides to keep their friendship a secret because of his anti-Semitic education and upbringing, yet at the same time he finds it hard to believe that all Jews are evil. On the other hand, his older sister Gretel (Amber Beattie) succumbs to the brainwashing and proceeds to hang Nazi posters on her bedroom walls. She abandons her dolls, for she believes she is not a child anymore, and stacks their naked plastic bodies in a pile eerily resembling the heaps of corpses so commonly found in concentration camps.Heavy with symbolism and filmed with a whimsical, fairytale feel, The Boy in the Striped Pajamas follows Bruno as he is placed in adult situations, forced to confront the emotional disintegration of his entire family and to reconsider his own beliefs after his life-changing experiences with Shmuel. The characters, like the dialogue, are simple, predictable, and placed in unrealistic situations, yet they are also well-developed and compelling. This is because the film is not so much an attempt at historical fiction as it is a tale with an important message. Thus, one must not expect this movie to be heavy on historical detail; instead, it uses the Holocaust mainly as a convenient backdrop to convey the moral of the story, that we are all human and deserve to be treated as such.The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is different from most other Holocaust films because it is viewed through the eyes of a child and effectively utilizes this perspective to demonstrate its purpose. Bruno's innocence and naïveté parallel the ignorance of the general population during that time period as well as the modern-day incomprehensibility of how such a terrible thing could have been allowed to happen. The film also stands out in its focus on the impact of the Holocaust on not only its victims, the Jews, but also its perpetrators, the Nazis. Despite the minimal shock footage of the Jews in the concentration camps, the film, with a twist ending, powerfully conveys its warning message with a sense of utter destruction and sheer hopelessness.

reviews.review_title: A very touching and heart breaking drama
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" is a fictional story that offers a unique perspective on how prejudice, hatred and violence affect innocent people, particularly children, during wartime. The movie is situated in WWII, the holocaust seen through the innocent eyes of Bruno, an eight year old kid and his forbidden friendship with Shmuel, a Jewish boy captive in a concentration camp. It is a movie full of drama, it is so touching and heart breaking that you can't hold your tears from dropping. The performances from all the cast are astonishing and breathe taking specially from the two kids (Asa Butterfield and Jack Scanlon). In conclusion, it is a movie that you will suffer but that it is definitely worthy and fully recommendable.

I saw this film on YouTube yesterday, and it's not left my mind since. It certainly gives you a lot to think about. The acting was one of the best things in the film. The main boy Bruno is played by Asa Butterfield who gave a spectacularly innocent performance. I recently saw him in Hugo and he didn't disappoint in that either. He is a truly talented actor and I'm sure we'll see more of him in the future. The other little boy was very good too, and David Thwelis was utterly repulsive as the Nazi officer. I won't go into the story or the ending because I think everyone knows what happens but if you don't, then watch this movie. It was really good, though devastatingly sad, and I wouldn't recommend it for young children. I'm 14, and I've studied the Holocaust but I was in pieces. If you don't cry then there's something wrong with you. 8/10

reviews.review_title: This film is not for the people lacking in intelligence
reviews.content: Contains mild spoilers. As is evident from reading some of the comment above this film is not for the people lacking in intelligence out there. It does not contain scenes of people killing each other every minute of the film; neither does it contain sex every five minutes. No this film is one to think about. It contains a very strong message about friendships and how they can form in the most unlikely environment. My partner and I went to see this film and then promptly re booked to see it the following day. The final scene is both devastating and powerful completed by a very strong music score. If you are looking for sex, drugs and American gang culture? don't waste your time. If you are after a film to get the grey matter working, and the tears flowing then get booking.

I was at Best Buy and rifling through the $7.99 Blu-ray bin and came across this film. I'm sorry I didn't see this a lot earlier. To me anyway, it was as powerful and mesmerizing as even Shawshank Redemption. I was glued to the TV, and the ending, while predictable, was no less dramatic. Excellent acting all the way around, including Vera Farmiga, one of the most beautiful women on screen. It's not a Holocaust movie as much as movie about family and friendships. The German boy does not yet understand that this Jewish boy should not be his friend. His innocence keeps him from learning the true meaning of his father's work. While the sister learns and converts, the mother realizes the wrong in what the father is doing. There is a scene where one of the Jews tends to a cut on the boy's knee; when she is informed that the Jew carried her boy inside and dressed the wound, the mother's compassion emerges as she thanks him. I cannot recommend this movie enough.

reviews.review_title: One of these instances when the last ten minutes of a movie elevate it to a haunting level of greatness.
reviews.content: Mark Herman's "Boy in the Striped Pyjamas" doesn't quite prepare you to how great it is, simply because everything happens in the end, and gives its full meaning to the poignant but rather predictable material featured in the first two acts.And watching this movie, I knew I would find comments on IMDb echoing my sentiment. After that extraordinary climax, I just told my wife: "this is the best ending the film could ever have", and by that, I meant the most logical and satisfying. She thought the film would show something more after that painful shot on the outside of the gas chamber and the remaining clothes, but I knew the film would immediately close, as it had made its point, and quite a powerful one. It's really one of these instances when the last ten minutes of a movie elevate it to a haunting level of greatness.Yes, the film is about a German boy, Bruno (played by Asa Butterfield) who doesn't know the extents of the atrocities committed by the very men he worships (or used to), including his father, which all naturally leads him to befriend a Jewish kid in a death camp, named Schmuel. Yes, childhood innocence at wartime and unlikely friendships are very common themes, and even the encounters between the two boys, at each side of barbed wire fences, doesn't really strike for its originality, but it's all in the last ten minutes, when Bruno dies in the gas chamber, with his friend and other men.And it's not about being happy for Bruno's death but since it was the worst punishment his father (David Thewlis) could ever have, yes it was a worthy sacrifice from a pure 'Karma' standpoint, in order to inflict the heartless officer what he's been routinely conducting toward innocent people. Even worse for him, is that the death of his son could have been easily avoided, if he had simply told him what the camp was about, and what they were doing there. Sure, that would have tarnished Bruno's admiration but he would have thought twice before playing games near the camp. And this is where the characterization of Bruno works and his fate, although tragic, is a great pay-off.Bruno is shown as a rather detached and solitary kid, less passionate and fanatic than his sister Gretel, but he's not all brave and courageous for all that, just curious and sweet. The title with the 'pyjama' description is a hint that the story is seen from an innocent child's perspective. And when Bruno is confronted to that young officer's anger, he denies being Schmuel's friend, which is a rather cowardly move. And even when he enters the camp, he seems very reluctant, so it must have taken one hell of a blind courage to ignore the risks of setting a foot in a camp. And this is the point: Bruno couldn't realize it, not because he was blind, but because he was blinded.The Germans supposedly ignored what happened in the Camp, so that when the Allies and Russians liberated them, they were shocked to discover the truth. Even the news report of a camp was pure propaganda, showing healthy prisoners eating and playing football. The German people believed it, because they wanted to believe it, they didn't want to think their leaders were Barbarians. And Bruno illustrates that mindset, when he sees the newsreel, he goes hug his father, suddenly becoming a good man who takes care of war prisoners. He was blinded by the propaganda, by his father's lies and also by his love as a son, as the Germans loved (for most of them) Hitler. It takes a believer to lie.As for the liar, Bruno's father knew what he did and we can wonder, if he's so proud of his actions and so confident that they're meant to save the German motherland, so why doesn't he openly talk about it? is it guilt or shame? No, pure denial. Denying people their right to live and exist, and denying that these actions are innately evil. The father is so wrapped up in that evil madness that he hypocritically kills people believing it's good while hiding this reality to his son, as if it wasn't so good. And this is where you reach the genius of the film, almost imperceptible, because it doesn't feel like a Spielberg or Polanski's super-production.Indeed, the soul of this film is an evil one. Sure, the father could have come at the last minute, or the shower be a real shower, like in "Schindler's List", but the father's arc had to be closed that way. He was the antagonist of the film, and the two kids' sacrifices the tool Destiny or Karma or God used to punish him. In fact, the film works like a reverse "Life is Beautiful", while Benigni pretended it was a game to keep his son's innocence and save his life, in "The Boy in Striped Pyjamas", the reality of the death camp is ignored by Bruno, and his maintained innocence ironically seals his fate.It's a tragic film but the irony is delightful because the father is responsible for his kids' obliviousness to the danger of the camp. And there's more to that, it is often asked how come the prisoners never fought or how come the Jews let themselves being arrested. Apart from the fact that this question ignores some heroic resistances, it also shows the sad reality, many of the Jewish people who died in these camps didn't know they would die, or that it would go as far as being separated from their families and put in gas chambers. And when you think about it, Bruno and even Schmuel, had the same mindset.Anything could happen, but death... yet it did, it was the most tragically satisfying ending the film could get.

This movie has a very nice,subtle plot. This kind of movies where a child is the lead actor is very tricky to do and I felt the director succeeded to pull this movie off but not up to its full potential. The innocent simplistic mind of a child was not given much importance. The movie could have been one notch higher if we had been put in the mind of the child, because it took me some time to get how would a child think under these conditions. I felt there were many loopholes in the plot. but anyway we are not supposed to look over these because the main thing in the movie is the innocence of a child and how the realization of the loss of child for a German soldier and devastating experience that the jews felt in those camps. The screenplay was very good in some parts and mediocre in the rest. It felt a little odd that the child does not ask his mother all this questions, I felt the tutor part a tad bit of a drag, I understood this was a crucial point of the film but was it that powerful so as to change the behavior of her sister ? The movie did not felt smooth if I had to clear. Well except all this facts the conversation between the two boys is really nice. This was the best part of the movie especially the Jew boy did an awesome job. That could emote his tension in the camp with the innocence of a child. Even his expressions were so subtle. This Jew boy was damn perfect throughout the movie. Well i may have rated it somewhat low, but believe me go watch this movie to experience the Nazi camps and its effect in poor souls.

reviews.review_title: Despite its flaws, this movie has some important haunting scenes
reviews.content: As other reviewers have written it before, this movie is not without flaws. No need to rehearse them again here. Despite this, or if you can see beyond them, you might be deeply touched by some scenes. Personally, I will never forget how Schmuel takes the hand of Bruno at the end of the movie. You just see their hands pressing each other. That's all you need to find enough strength in order to carry on, despite all the flaws, all the atrocities around them, around us, despite Farmiga's desperate cry under the rain. For better or worse, this simple shot of one second or two has been engraved in my mind and will stay with me.

reviews.review_title: A good film, but nowhere near great
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is a good film. It has some beautiful cinematography and set designs. The characters and writing are solid, but the film reaches greatness too late. I know that the film was leading up to something bigger, and boy did the ending pack a punch! I saw this film in my school classroom and when the ending came everyone went silent. The ending was definitely great, but to me the rest of the film, while never really dull, is never that interesting to begin with. It does have some great scenes, however. The performances are also rich, especially Vera Farmiga, who is proving that she is an actress to watch out for! I just wish the film was overall more engaging, but I still do recommend it.

reviews.review_title: What is the author's message and who, or what, do the movie's characters represent to you?
reviews.content: In my opinion this is a good movie/book because it has basic moral appeal and an enduring message, and because this movie (and probably the book to an even greater degree) can have symbolic or abstract meaning in regard to the characters and what they represent in terms of history, national identity, and humanity.I think this quote accurately describes the moral message of the movie: A timeless story of innocence lost and humanity found. The message of the movie is that human beings are born innocent. We are born to love and we become friends with anyone regardless of race / religion / orientation, etc. However, as we grow old, we grow corrupted, and then we lose our innocence and become more prejudiced and filled with hate (well a lot of people, but not all). So in the end, the movie is saying that we are all the same, we are all human beings, and it is the silly, narrow, immoral things that divide and ruin us. None of us are immune to this behavior, so we must always remember that if we don't watch ourselves it can happen again.I would like to see other reviewer's interpretation and analysis of, the message of the movie and who or what the characters symbolically represent... There is no right or wrong answer, only your personal opinion(s).So, what is the author's message and who, or what, do the movie's characters represent to you?

reviews.review_title: This certainly isn't a bedtime story.
reviews.content: If I were to have a problem with this otherwise stunning film it's the fact that, much like 'The Dark Knight' this is not a film you want to take your kids to. Its dark, disturbing and one of the best weepers of this fine year. Anybody above the ages of fifteen, you must see this movie. It might not beat 'The Dark Knight' with style or substance but this is without a doubt the most important film of the year. The imagery is so disturbing, you have to remind yourself, it's just a movie. But here's where there no escape, this isn't Last House on the Left. This is real, this is a film based on a novel of the same named based on historical events of a German family moving to a country house near a concentration camp and their son befriending one of the boys inside the camps. And if your hearts not in your heart during that unbearably tense final act then something is painfully wrong with you. These final minutes are so disturbing i broke out inot a cold sweat, Even stranger is how I allowed this to slip under my radar for weeks. I remember reading the book that this is based on when I was young. I remember loving it. And now I find it just wonderful how much the makers of this film have done it justice. During World War II, 8-year-old Bruno (Asa Butterfield) and his family leave Berlin to take up residence near the concentration camp where his father (David Thewlis) has just been made commandant. Bruno is unhappy and lonely, until one day, when he wanders out behind his house and finds Shmuel (Jack Scanlon), a Jewish boy his own age. Though the barbed-wire fence of the camp separates the boys, they enter into a forbidden friendship, oblivious to the true nature of their surroundings.If i were to complain about this film, plausibility is where I would start. Its exaggerated for sure. The lack of authentic German accents, the seemingly absent guards and an overall sense that this wouldn't have gone in that direction. All however is quite easily redeemed with its tear jerker, heart stopping ending.As difficult as it may be to watch, it should certainly be a film that everybody sees if only for the realisation that this horrific event occurred. If you're willing to forgive some implacability faults and a couple of odd accents then you'll walk out of this film feeling stunned with just how horrific the truth is.Verdict: a painful yet fully accomplished journey, that will appeal solely to those who can withstand the disturbing imagery, erry settings and that holy mary mother of god ending that will have you clenching your jaw in hope they make a copout ending. To our dissatisfaction, they don't. And while it might have been more releasing it would have spoilt the realisation. For what its worth this is film of the year material.
A poignant and moving film that tells the story of two children with overwhelming cruelty. It has some narrative flaws which, however, are nil in the face of the grandeur of the story being told.

reviews.review_title: Should have been nominated for some Oscars
reviews.content: This was perhaps the most powerful 'fiction' movie I have seen in a long time. Seriously this movie moved me in ways I expected and not. I am not going to give any spoilers, but I will say that true friendship can develop between anyone regardless of the situation or age. Perhaps our hope in this world lies with the innocence of children, perhaps not. Its OK to dream. The circumstances that arose from this movie , was done meticulously from each person in 'said' situation. The 2 protagonists in this movie were children that were wise beyond their age .... yet they did not know any better. It is a paradox to be sure , but certainly a paradox worth paying to see. Treat yourself to this wonderful movie. I give it a 9 only because it did lose authenticity points for the Brit accents. I am guessing it was low budget. Getting by the unrealistic accents... I truly believe this to be the best movie of 2008. You will not be disappointed.

This is a very moving film that features an 8 year old child's perspective to illuminate the horror of the Holocaust, both in terms of the obvious effect on its persecuted victims as well as the insidious damage inflicted on the family structure of the perpetrators. From the outset we are given an insight into Bruno, the young son of a Nazi commandant father that foretells in some measure what will transpire. The boy is seen careening through the streets of Berlin with two friends, his love of play and companionship quite evident. When his father's duties require the family to move to a remote, isolated residence nearby a concentration camp (Auschwitz?), the viewer immediately senses that this boy who views himself as an explorer will undergo an experience that will challenge his limited capacity to comprehend at this stage of his life. This aspect takes up much of the film, and is highlighted by the burgeoning friendship of the German boy with a Jew (Shmuel) of his own age who resides in the camp. The total innocence of the dialog between the two boys is especially poignant in view of the horrific context in which these two unlikely friends find themselves.The acting by all the characters throughout is marvelous, the boys as well as the mother (Vera Farmiga) who becomes increasingly horrified by what is occurring not only around her but also within her marriage. Her rejection is conveyed not only in terms of dialog but also by the clothing and makeup of this beautiful young mother as she chooses to become increasingly drab, befitting her recognition that dress and makeup cannot and should not gloss over the horror of her surroundings and of her marriage to someone she has come to view as a monster. The damage done to the German family as mentioned earlier is not only shown by the deterioration of the marriage of Bruno's parents, but is also alluded to at the funeral of the paternal grandmother. Similarly, a young lieutenant who has a significant role in the film is viewed critically by the Nazi regime for not reporting the "treasonous" behavior of his professor father's emigration to Switzerland.An interesting subtext of the film is how differently people, young and old in Nazi German society behaved during this terrible time. On the one hand are the sensitive and humanity-inspired figures of the mother, grandmother, Bruno, Shmuel, the elderly physician/kitchen helper victim, and the lieutenant's father (unseen) who fled Germany. More than balancing those figures are the negative characterizations of the father, grandfather, Bruno's gullible elder sister, the children's tutor and the young, cruel lieutenant.This is a very thoughtful film for both adults and older children/teenagers, its ironic title belying the seriousness of this film. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: Profound war film - with a difference
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is one of those II WW dramas where war events are in the background, beyond, i.e. no proximate battles around, but idyllic life is soon spoiled by horrible things difficult to cover as the war advances. And typically to all totalitarian regimes, one must always take sides, choose and prove his/her loyalty, hesitating or opposing in any way is not tolerated. This is all especially confusing and tragic for children, as they have misshapen and vague picture due to two main reasons: their limited comprehension as well the fact that adults try to gloss them over nasty things.The storyline of the film advances smoothly and is rather credible, the only thing that seemed strange to me was how those boys could meet so openly for so long time? What about guards and/or electrical fences? Using this corner, many could have escaped... The ending is unanticipated and forms a sharp contrast with the pace before.The cast is great, especially Vera Farmiga as Elsa, Asa Butterfield as Bruno (far better performance than in blockbuster Hugo) and David Thewlis as Ralf. As for the director Mark Herman, it is his best (and for some reason or another) last film so far.

reviews.review_title: Interesting idea, but does not lead anywhere.
reviews.content: The film tries to show us that two boys became friends despite the social differences. One is a jew in a camp, the other is a son of nazi commander. I understand that it's supposed to show tolerance for jews, but the story leads nowhere. Movie ends with german boy getting inside the camp to search for the father of the jew boy and they both die in the showers. I did not felt sad for it, it felt very forced sad ending, just cutting the story.

A child's view of one of the worst atrocities of the 20th century.The film is so innocent and sweet at times yet so evil and brutal moments later.The ending is as shocking as 'let him have it' another film with an ending that shook me to my very core.A must see film.

When I first heard of "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" I was terribly excited to see it. I am a huge WWII fan and an avid Holocaust buff. I've read books, watched movies, and written research papers on the near annihilation of the Jews. I thought "The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" would advocate what I had long known and become passionate about. Boy was I wrong."The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" begins with little Bruno moving from his nice home in Berlin to a walled-in home in the country. It is only a few miles from a supposed 'farm' and Bruno hopes to make friends there. It would turn out that the 'farm' is actually a concentration camp full of Jews eventually condemned to the gas chambers. Bruno's dad is the commandant of this camp. Bruno (illegally) befriends a little Jewish boy in the camp. That's only the beginning of this woeful tale This movie is for those that are already WWII fans. There is no 'set-up' or introduction of why the Jews were persecuted and there is no violence or gore. For me, there was none needed. I know what atrocities the Nazis were guilty of. The idea that this is all portrayed through the eyes of a child was very strange. I'm accustomed to more mature movies on this subject such as Uprising, so it was hard to get use to.I will admit that some of the movie was very touching. When Lieutenant Kotler dug himself into a hole that there was no getting out of, I felt downright sorry for him. And the Jewish boy's face when he is beaten looked sooo terrible....Though the movie had its touching moments, the reality was that what happened in the movie would not have ever happened in real life. A boy could not have dug himself into Auschwitz. He would not have talked to someone through the electric gates. It just would not have happened.Two things bugged me the most. The first was the assumption that Bruno was so dumb as to not know what was going on. It is possible that he would have been sheltered from the idea of the gas chambers, (much like his Mother was) but coming from a military family and how his sister turned into a Hitler youth wannabe, he would of known that the Jews were to be stayed away from. Kids aren't that dumb. He would of figured it out that it was some sort of communal camp. A farm??? Seriously? The second was merely how over-dramatized the ending was. The music was so loud in the theater; I thought my eardrum was going to pop. How did the mother know her son was dead? Was she psychic? The father was a bit more realistic. What really got me was how after blaring all that music, the movie ended quietly with the camera focused on the gas chamber door and the lights gradually dimming. I feel like a lot of Holocaust movies end like that..."The Boy in the Striped Pajamas" might have ended with a moment of reverence to those who lost their lives in the Holocaust, but the rest of the film was almost a spoof. For the dedicated at heart, skip this one and go re-watch "Uprising" or "Schindler's List." Something worth your time and money.

This movie left me feeling that somehow - on some level - the holocaust had become part of my own personal experience. It left me deeply reflective of the moral responsibility that we all have, but can all too easily shirk, concerning our dealings with other human beings. The people who criticise this movie because some of the details may not be absolutely correct are, I think, missing the point. It is not about precise facts, and doesn't pretend to be - the book of the same name that the movie is based on is subtitled "a fable". This movie is concerned with truth other than the strictly factual kind.
