I thought this was most touching scene of the film to that point.Finally in the end there is our own horror at what happens to Bruno who we have come to like and come to ultimately respect his own humanity and the lesson that evil destroys a part of the evil doer as well as the victim.To say that I was moved by this film underestimates its impact. This film is second only to Schindler's List in my estimation in its ability to enlighten us all on the horror of the holocaust. If this film is not at least nominated for Best Picture, I will be very disappointed.

reviews.review_title: A film you will never forget
reviews.content: The history of the Holocaust has been told many times in every format. However this movie has a little twist that leaves you numb. Why? Because it explains simply, that whatever Atrocities humankind inflicts on others; you have already done the same to your own. And you remain thinking, why don't we all have that perspective at all times, or why hasn't it changed us to be better human beings?

reviews.review_title: The Boy in Striped Pajama review
reviews.content: Boy this is a sad movie. As many of you know I am a huge fan of sad movies and when I saw the trailers for this movie, I just knew. I remember watching the trailers for this when I was seeing another movie and I turned to the person I was sitting by and said, That movie about the boy in striped pajamas is going to be terribly sad. Boy was I right on that one. But what makes it so good is that it reminds us to be human. I won't tell you what happens. I give it a good review because, as many of you know, I am fond of good acting. Boy does this have it. What I will say is that the boy who is Asa is a really good actor. Even though he's so young!!! It reminds me of that child actor who was in Empire of the Sun, a good war movie this time by Steven Spielberg. This movie is about the Nazis. If you are thinking of Indiana Jones Nazis then you will be mistaken. If you are thinking Band of Brothers Nazis then you will still be mistaken but getting closer to the point. Also these are definitely NOT Hogans Heroes Nazis. Well until next time America...

reviews.review_title: This one is going to stick with me for a very long time
reviews.content: I'm trying to avoid spoilers here but am not sure if I can give my opinion on this movie without giving away a little more than I'm comfortable with.Keeping the end of the movie out of it for the time being, I found the story told in this movie to be a bit of a different perspective than most.It was centered on quite a normal family. The dad, personally, was quite pleasant, likable guy and appeared to have a very good relationship with his family. A supportive guy with a sucky job. As the movie progressed he lost some of his appeal and became not quite as likable but I feel it was believable that this was due to the stress of his job and escalating estrangement from his family.Watching how the sister had no problem being brainwashed to the cause gave me a bit of a better understanding of how so many could be swayed to support the Nazi cause believing they were really in the right.Now to my reaction of the ending ...... after sitting in stunned silence when it was all over, I proceeded to throw up! I can't even say whether with the ending as it was I can overall say I enjoyed the movie or not - I am still absolutely reeling! Is it the type of ending that provokes deep emotions - definitely. Is it the type of ending that will stick with you for a long long time - for sure. Do I wish it ended differently - absolutely. I don't think I could honestly say whether I liked the ending without stewing on it for a couple weeks.Definitely worth the watch!

Let me start talking about how Holocaust movies can really make me feel uncomfortable. Even though I fully enjoy them, I do not agree with how the Jews were treated during that time. Although, this does not mean we should not learn about it.What I mostly found wrong about the movie was the actors. I may not be an expert on accents, I believe they sounded more British then German. Also the plot does not seem right, I do not think that they would allow families to move near the Concentration Camps. Also, there would have been guards around where they met. The guards would have told Bruno to leave the camp and not come back. Near the end of the film when Bruno got under the fence, it would have not been so easy. I believe that before he got there the solider would have stopped them from doing anything else. I'm pretty sure they worked really hard to make sure that only the Jews would get killed in the gas chambers. However, I can go easy on the movie because this is not based on a true story.What I liked about the movie was how it made you think about the treatment of the Jews during WWII. I also liked how Bruno was different from the rest of the Germans during that time. He was one of the very few back then to realize that not all the Jews were terrible people. After all, if they were bad people then Bruno and Schmuel wouldn't have been friends. I felt pretty sensitive at some scenes, like with the end and when Schmuel was caught eating a cake while he was a slave in the house. I was also uncomfortable when I saw the scene when he was in the camp. I guess it's because I was sensing that Bruno was uncomfortable.I'll recommend this film to anyone who just wants to know the basics about the Holocaust. I don't think his film is historically accurate enough for school.

I am not a fan of war type movies but was asked to attend to keep a friend company. I have never read the book or heard of the movie before I went to see the film. My first notion before I attended cinema was I expected it to be boring. However I quickly changed my mind. Even though the actors were unknown to me I thought they were great. Throughout the movie I was quite fixated and near the end it became very intense. It was a very emotional movie and very quiet with a few wet eyes at the end. It was kind of disbelieving. The movie was about the holocaust during World War 2. It gave viewers an insight to other side of the story by way of how it might have been for the German people who had been brain washed into a certain way of thinking about the concentration camps because of manipulation by SSO propaganda. It did this through the innocent eyes of a child and how confused he felt about his friend when his father and teacher, the people he trusted talked about the evils of Jews. It demonstrated the intolerance towards the Jewish community and anyone that showed empathy towards them. However my critique is in reality things would have been much harsher in the camp and I don't believe the little boy in the camp would have ever got that close to the perimeter fence as it would have been very much guarded. I highly recommend the film.

reviews.review_title: A challenging, heart-breaking and brilliant movie
reviews.content: A powerful piece of film-making that stayed with me long after I walked out of the cinema. Nicely paced, disturbing and brilliant. An intriguing look at one of the darkest chapters of human history, and by telling the tale through the eyes of the innocent and charming eight year old Bruno, they have come up with a way to give a new voice to a genre that is known for its heart breaking brutality.There is violence here as well I suppose, but it is an implied violence – violence that occurs just around the corner and out of eyeshot for Bruno. You know that it is taking place on both a personal and systemic level, but you never really witness it directly. It shows the sort of understated subtlety we've come to expect from Director Mark Herman (Brassed Off, Little Voice) who has turned in another impressive film here.Asa Butterfield is cast perfectly as Bruno, showing the right sort of charm and wide eyed innocence that allows this movie to move along at a steady pace, without becoming mired in the details of the atrocities that are occurring around him. David Thewlis (The Harry Potter Series) also deserves a mention for his outstanding portrayal as Bruno's Dad. Some movies hurt like a kick to the groin but leave you all the better for it. This is one of those movies.Full review here for those with an interest.http://cinestuff.wordpress.com

"CHILDHOOD IS MEASURED OUT BY SOUNDS AND SMELLS AND SIGHTS, BEFORE THE DARK HOUR OF REASON GROWS", that's the phrase at the beginning of this poignant story. One of the most powerful holocaust movies ever made. It's not a 'movie', it's an earth shaking experience that must be watched to comprehend the cruelty, inhumanity, and ruthlessness that adult people are capable of. This incredible motion picture gets you involved and care about each characters, especially the innocent children, and grabs your essence so powerfully that you want to scream. Moreover, the intensity builds up tenfold because the horrible acts are not shown, while your mind perceives everything. But be embraced, you'll find yourself trembling at the end, literally.

reviews.review_title: Point well made without graphic violence and numerous obscenities!
reviews.content: This is what I call telling the story, in good taste, without needless violence and profanity!Wartime content and hate-based theme still require age appropriation.

reviews.review_title: An excellent film, well thought through.
reviews.content: In my opinion, this film should be part of the national curriculum for history studies. The 'Nazi' attitude is clearly displayed without graphic violence. The innocence of the friendship of the two boys, and the 'growing up' of the 12 year old girl offer an insight to what may have actually happened. At least that's the message I took from the film, and it would be interesting if any other folk would agree, or not. The fact that no attempt to hide the attitude from the two children was a little disturbing. Also blocking the view out of one window as it overlooked the 'camp' was also a bit of a shock. I would definitely recommend this film to anyone who has an interest in the second world war period.

...and probably more of an insult to the intelligence of >1,100,000 Jews who died in Auschwitz than, say, Mein Kampf. If a naive 8-year old can get into the death camp just by crawling under the fence - just to play Explorers with a depressed-looking peer, who fails entirely to convince as a likely friend, mind you - then why was there not a whole series of successful escapes? This film is a simple vehicle built on the simplistic thought "What would those nazis have said if it had been THEIR children!" The story is pathetic, unbelievable, and - while beautifully filmed - deserving of the very lowest rating, because it has already convinced far too many people that it is based on true events, or has any important cultural qualities.

reviews.review_title: From book to movie - highly dissapointed.
reviews.content: PS! I WOULD RECOMMEND ANYONE OUT THERE TO WATCH A MOVIE WHICH ARE BASED ON A BOOK BEFORE READING THE BOOK. IF YOU DO THE OPPOSITE ORDER, AS ME, YOU WILL PROBABLY BE HUGELY DISAPPOINTED. READ MY BIBLE-LENGTH REVIEW TO FIND OUT WHY.From reading a splendid and great book where you see a war and cruelty from a not knowing 9 year old boy (Bruno) that loves exploration, one would have high expectation for the movie, which was my case. I really enjoyed reading the book from Bruno's view of point, which I think was the best. I was greatly disappointed seeing the movie from the viewers view of point and not his. I partly understand why they did that. It was to save screentime, but nevertheless, that was half of the point. In order to understand Bruno's strange behavior one had to see the world from his view of point. I felt the director and movie wasn't able to deliver that. That is my greatest disappointment with the movie.It didn't only stop there. Next, they rushed the movie. Jumped over many important great details. In the book Gretel was in love with Lieutenant Kotler. She only threw her dolls once he was moved to the Eastern front. Indirectly it shown that she had grown-up from being a kid with dolls to a teen that would use her whole day to track her beloved Kotler. Contrary with the book ,the movie wasn't able to show that. From being a doll lover she spontaneously threw them away to praise Nazism out of nowhere. How did she become a brainwashed Nazi. I felt the book was able to convey her personality much better.Next, I really didn't like how they exaggerated everything and made more drama than necessary. For instance, the book ended with Shumel and Bruno holding hands, giving the reader impression that their friendship and bond couldn't be broken by any cruelty thrown to them by the Nazi's. Thus, we end up with a good aftertaste, though it had a sad end. You were satisfied because you knew that their friendship was so strong and powerful that even in death it wouldn't weakened of be diminished. This feeling was totally ruined in the movie where they focused more the cruelty of the holocaust and the drama of their family finding Bruno. In my opinion, the scene with his mother was totally unnecessary.There were more scenes I don't remember right now, but they totally ruined a great chance to visualize a great book. Real sad and missed opportunity.
Good film. I like films on history and wwii. I'll give it another thing though. It ain't have fakin sad. Good tho.

reviews.review_title: Why is this film so highly praised?
reviews.content: The Boy In The Striped Pyjamas is probably one of THE most overrated films about the extermination of the Je- wait, it's barely even about that, it just brushes over that issue. The film lets us watch a spoilt brat play about in his house, then abuse his power over another child, how am I meant to feel any sympathy at all for this character? The ending is unnecessarily extreme and in my opinion, has warped people's views of the film. Instead of looking at production value and acting talent, they have just focused on events in the closing ten minutes.Schindler was enough, can we leave the Holocaust to the great film makers please.

reviews.review_title: A grim tale told through the eyes of children on both sides of Nazi Germany.
reviews.content: "We're not supposed to be friends, you and I. We're meant to be enemies. Did you know that?"This film, while very well made, is quite unsettling to watch the entire way through. At times it is sweet, but mostly sad and upsetting. It shows the naivety and the innocence of both a wealthy German boy and a Jewish boy in a concentration camp who begin a forbidden friendship. Both of the children suffer the same horrific fate at the end of the movie, unaware of what they've got coming to them. It's definitely not for the faint of heart.

reviews.review_title: Huge Story From The Eyes of a Child
reviews.content: I've recently just watched the film, and It's brilliant. The film fires up your emotions as you look at the phenomenal friendship of Bruno and Shmuel. This film will test you as the irresistible plot keeps you asking for more. I was impressed by how they were able to change a book into a huge journey. The story takes place back in the Holocaust. We see a boy called Bruno running with his friends as the title credits play. He then moves into a new town at Outwith where he struggles to cope with his new home. He journeys off into the wilderness and finds a boy called Shmuel on the other side of the fence. We then see their friendship evolve immensely as they continue to see each other every day. Later on, Bruno promises Shmuel to try and find his father after Bruno had betrayed Shmuel. The following event that occurs contains dark scenery, a breath taking climax. Unfortunately, the friends die together burning. The mood in these scenes will make the emotional weep for their loss. Overall, the story is brilliant and contains a lot of twists that will test the viewer. One thing I dislike about the film is how they cut out two interesting scenes from the book. Despite being an adaption and re-written, I think that those two scenes would create more tension and effect to the performance of the film. On top of that, the quality of the film balanced out the disadvantages. The lighting is absolutely perfect and it seems to contrast in some scenes. In the camp, the lighting is dark and gloomy, and at the beginning the lighting is gold and bright. Huge differences in effects like this give variety to the film. I could compare this film to War Horse because of the drama and variety of effects. Bruno is a typical nine year old who has a good manner and a love for adventure books. He is a great character to associate with Shmuel. Speaking of Shmuel, Shmuel is an original and kind character who easily forgives and has a heart of gold. The worst character for me is Maria. Because of her missing a scene from her book, her character seems two dimensional and doesn't get as much screen time as Bruno. Also Gretel isn't as full of character as in the book. Fortunately, those are the only issues I have with the characters. In conclusion, The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas is phenomenal. I think that they did a great job with this movie. The plot is brilliant. The twists are unexpected and this is a breath taking experience overall. I'll give this film an 8.5/10

reviews.review_title: WOW. Watch this film. Right now.
reviews.content: I'm not usually interested in any films/books set in wartime, but this is so much more than a war movie. It is a beautifully made film with exquisite acting in every scene. The characters are full of depth and conflict and the plot is at once very accessible, emotive and intensely thought-provoking. This is the story of a young boy and his family who move house due to his father's promotion. Everything is seen through the eyes of the eight-year-old and we quickly empathise with his distress at leaving his friends and his grandparents behind, his boredom in his new - very restricted - environment and his confused emotions regarding his father, who appears a loving, caring man, and his job as a leading Nazi soldier. The child is initially unaware that the new friend he makes is Jewish, but their friendship proves to have unforeseen consequences. This film has an amazing plot, it's beautifully made and superbly acted. It has affected me strongly and I'm so glad I've watched it. Brilliant.

reviews.review_title: Deeply flawed, inferior to many others
reviews.content: Choosing only English-speaking actors and having them speak with almost Received Pronunciation was a baffling decision. Films about WWII in the last decade or so have almost entirely opted to use actors speaking the correct language. I am aware this film was partly for children, but they can read too. Even an attempt at German or Eastern European accents would have been better.For most of the film, the light, unchallenging tone makes it appear to be Enid Blyton's 'Five Go to Death Camp'. Before the final scene, we see no guards; the watchtowers appear to be empty; the forced labour in the camp is so slow that a half-built shed never gets any further throughout the film; the security perimeter is so easy to penetrate that a small boy can dig under it without anyone noticing; both boys meet many times, also with no consequences for the inmate; the ridiculous coincidence that the day Bruno enters the camp is the same one his friend is due to be killed; Bruno and his (apparently) Eastern European friend have no language difficulties; the whole message of the film appears to be that killing one blue-eyed German child was far worse than a whole shed full of Jews...There are much better films about this.
Quite possibly the worst film I have ever seen. Ridiculously inaccurate nonsense.

I've got to say that this film was totally spoiled by being made in English. It is not easy to see people with posh English accents as being German, would have been much better to make the film in German.The acting on the whole is quite poor but the blond guard was pretty good. The story was relayed quite slowly, unrealistically and not very consistent with its era.Overall the film is really good, due to the plot being good, it could've been pulled off much better though. It's a shame it wasn't filmed using a decent director and decent actors.Not related to the film but on the subject of language - it's pyjamas, not pajamas. The language is English, notice how it isn't called American and is called English. Please stop trying to mess with our words, swapping s's for z's and removing u's and swapping other letters and then writing software that changes our correct spelling to your incorrect spelling. AAArrgghhh frustrating!!!!

reviews.review_title: Great moving movie, but the ending did fall a bit short.
reviews.content: To start off, I am a very emotional young man, and I've cried or teared up for plenty of movies before, but for some reason, this movie did not make me shed a single tear, but more into that in a few.This movie was overall very good. I enjoyed watching it. Bruno, the main character was not only cute, but was played very well. At moments it seemed Bruno wanted to say something, or think something, but instead, he was portrayed with the all familiar face of childhood misunderstanding, a cold bewildered silence, and it suites the situation very well.(SPOILERS) I'm not alone when I say this, but the ending could have been better. Yes, it has been mentioned by a few that the non-graphic nature of this movie enables it to be accessible to young ones, but I still think they should have shown his father walk into the chamber to see his son, gone. His mother breaking down and screaming in anguish and pain really hit home on me, but when it showed his father, stand there, stone cold, like he's waiting for something, it just ruined the moment and made me a bit mad. Seeing him realize what his "cause" has done would have created such a better ending, and I would have easily cried.I love these kinds of movies, even though they make me so sad. Just a depressing movie like Requiem for a Dream, where at the end, all you can say is "Wow".

I think I might have seen one of the praises for this movie before I decided to watch it. The trailer is also promising. The movie? No.Starting from the first scenes I realized I don't want to see this movie (but I was there, why not stay?). The actors are acting so poor that you almost try to guess where the camera crew was when they were filming. Most camera movements are shaky, the framing of the scenes is sometimes lacking "magic". The movie is very predictable, you can always guess what happens next and the dynamic is very slow. Just a few things happen until the last 15 minutes of the movie. The story takes its time to unwind and then the ending is very intense but is suddenly very dense after all the first part of the story. The characters are cartoonish and lack the power of "who" and "why". David Thewlis's character is probably the most cartoonish of them all. It is so very not believable.I said the actors are poor. I'll take some of that back. Vera Farmiga is a good actress and has great potential with a good director. The kids do a great job as well. The plot could have made a good movie. Maybe next time...

reviews.review_title: A promising story that's horribly translated into film
reviews.content: While watching the film I had no doubt that the book would be an amazing one to read. It's a story with an awful lot of potential. However, the film doesn't come near to the atmosphere other films about the 2nd world war and the holocaust manage to create. The fact that the actors speak fluent English instead of German gives you the feeling that you're watching a pretty cheap film. Add a sudden change of weather (thunder and rain) when the scene is getting serious, and you really feel like you as an audience is not taken seriously at all. The actor who plays the boy in the striped pyjamas is not convincing and the characters aren't well thought out. There is no subtlety in the film. Everything is handed to you so you don't require to do any thinking yourself. The child's view could be interesting but is not well presented. The main character is presented to you at first as quite a smart and observing child, just to act in a way later on in the film that is in complete contrast with his previous behaviour. A predictable film that adds nothing to the genre and is completely unbelievable. The fact that it was only 90 minutes was the only reason for me to watch it till the end.

But this movie didn't break my heart. I find the plot very hollow and as much filled with nothing but the vague story you get from a trailer. I understand it has the ultimate memory value for someone facing the past of their families and ancestors, but the movie - as a movie itself was quite bad by my opinion and anyone broken down by couple of scenes of depressed people showing up in this movie is really easy to get moved by anything.Ending of the movie was predictable from the very beginning, the main kid, Bruno, had such a transparent role that made me bored and wasn't at all interesting, no matter how much it was meant to present the naivety of German people from that time. Yes I sighed a couple of times watching it, and I find the theme of Holocaust very disturbing part of the world history... But this movie just didn't make it for me, I just don't find it good enough. Maybe because I'm not Jewish? If this is a movie made for children, then it's OK, if not, it needed a lot more working on the script and the plot itself. The way it is and as it is - it's only 94 minutes of waiting for the inevitable, which is not enough for me to rate it better. Call me desensitized, but I've seen much better done with less $ than this.

reviews.review_title: "Their lost voices Must continue to be heard"
reviews.content: This is a very philosophical film with a deep meaning. The most important thing that makes a film valuable is that we are made to think. If you start a killing machine, sooner or later, it will affect you. I wish there were more of these films to remember thet we all have a heart that can worry about other people.

reviews.review_title: I didn't know what to expect
reviews.content: Seeing Bruno's acceptance of Shmuel despite his father's outlook was touching. I was doing fine with this movie until a few scenes after Bruno denied knowing Shmuel, when they are at the fence again together and Shmuel looks up. I emotionally lost it. And the final few scenes were a killer for me.

I don't have many words to describe this movie. Powerful....impactful...just the sheer love that these two children show to each other...even through the most difficult moments....is just so warming and heartbreaking at the same time at so many points. Bravo! If you don't cry or even well up after this...your just not human...

A classic subject and an elaborated time period. All people have something they have heard/ watched about 2nd World War and the applications of the Nazi Germany. This time it was illuminated for both aspects, neither for the German soldiers nor the Jewish people back then only. Cast choice is definitely perfect and indeed reflects the national appearance of the people. The only part I didn't enjoy was that how people didn't speak German in the movie. It's really OK for a quality audience to watch a subtitled movie, I guess and thus national differences and the realistic atmosphere is conserved. Especially German people shouldn't have a British accent, NO. It really spoils the realistic atmosphere. Other than that the tragedy of the movie, the annihilation of childhoods and a dictator's pressure on people was shown very adequately.
This was a sad and heartbreaking movie that shows you that you have so much to be blessed about. This is a must see
Life has given me two beautiful gifts. The first being my MOM and the second is the pleasure of watching the movie. Period.

I came on to this site to read about this film before going to see it at the Cinema. I read with enthusiasm the reports of it and as my wife usually weeps at sad films I packed an extra 2 packets of tissues for the supposed emotional turmoil we were about to endure.This film is a very slow starter, I knew before I started to watch it, it was only 1 hour 25 mins long so after 60 minutes I was starting to get a little impatient.I was disappointed to say the least, it wasn't a particularly good story and I seemed to miss the brilliant acting I was lead to believe by reading these other reviews / synopsis.I looked over at my wife at the end of the film and she looked back at me with a 'thanks for wasting 1 and a half hours of my time' look, NO TEARS, well maybe a few of anger.I think 7.9/10 average is more than generous for this film, it's OK if there is nothing else that takes your fancy but I wouldn't make a special journey to see it.

quite simply, this film is the best movie ever made... it will leave you stunned... people who don't understand will never understand... if you like to be challenged, you will be challenged beyond comprehension... if you wan truth then you will find truth... if you want emotion you will find emotion.This movie MUST be seen by all.. it is a masterpiece that ranks with the greatest masterpieces ever. In a hundred years this movie will outlast the multi million dollar pieces of manure being made in Hollywood today.And thats it in a nutshell.. no more need be said.

reviews.review_title: Interesting outsider perspective, but not as sad as other Holocaust movies
reviews.content: I heard many people say this movie was a "tear-jerker," but I must disagree. As a Jew, I have seen my fair share of Holocaust movies and I felt that this movie paled in comparison to the emotions evoked in other movies. Maybe its because its not the harshest and grittiest display of the reality of the horrors that were part of the Holocaust.I do, however, like that this story is about an outside perspective. This is just my opinion and I can respect this film for bringing any bit of awareness to people who haven't watched or heard other stories and portrayals of this specific time period.I would have preferred if they hired German-speaking actors with an authentic accent but speaking English (for the sake of the audience).

reviews.review_title: More detail and accuracy for the period required.
reviews.content: While I enjoy this film and think the actors all did a good job - there are things about the movie that irritate me and make it difficult to be completely absorbed.Opening scenes of the movie where Bruno and his friends come home from school, while playing aeroplanes - The people portrayed in the scene all look like they are perfectly turned out with spotless and new out of the shop clothing. It makes it all look rather false and hard to take as real people going about their business.I know the story is a fable and we have to suspend our imagination to accept the tale and it's final outcome but I would prefer as much detail and accuracy as possible where by it is part of the era and Third Reich of the time.I would guess that the story is set during the 1941 or 1942 period when gassing of Jewish people was taking place.During that period Jewish people would have already been deported or had emigrated to other neighbouring countries, that then became swallowed up by the Nazis and so they fell under the control of the murderous regime - The Third Reich. Jews in the German cities would have been non people and would have been few and far between.Deportation of Jews would have been done under cover of night or very, early in the morning so that ordinary German citizens would not have to see what was done by their government and in their name.The music played at the party in Bruno's parents home would not have been swing or jazz music. This was much frowned upon and outlawed by good Nazis.Just a couple of easy things to remedy and should have been executed a little better.

This is a brilliant adaptation of a compelling book. The movie contains all the key elements of the book, down to the point that from the very beginning I was haunted by the ending. The story telling is not understated but stated, and the musical score evocative. The result is engrossing.However, having relived the story twice, I am not so sure. The writer, John Boyne, was born in 1971 in Dublin. This is a confection, not just in the sense of being a wonderful piece of craft, but being sweet, or more correctly bitter sweet. But is it also a contrived confection? Much of the work on the holocaust has been important because it opens us up to new perspectives and teaches us key moral lessons. But repetition dulls even the sharpest of scalpels. At times there was a nagging sense that I was being tunneled along a well trodden road.

This film was fantastic. Even though everyone knows the history of the Holocaust, this film is sure to make people think. The whole time, I was reminded that people actually felt that way about other human beings; that they would treat them like animals and even call them that. It is not a movie you can watch over and over, but it certainly is one everyone should see. The ending, while awful, was also perfect. There is no other way it could have ended. When I saw this film, I wasn't quite prepared for it. My friend and I were bored one night and decided to borrow a movie. I sat up late that night thinking about the human race and wondering if there is hope for us.

reviews.review_title: A German child befriends a Jewish child during World War II
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is truly an original take on the Holocaust during World War II. It is seen from the perspective of a child. It not only shows the Holocaust through a child's eyes, but through the eyes of a German child and a Jewish child. This film captivates the audience through to the very last scene. It is not very historical like other Holocaust films, such as Schindler's List. It focuses on the relationship between a German child and a Jewish child in a concentration camp. As their friendship develops, both children grown in different ways, as they try to see the world through each others eyes. It is definitely a film worth seeing!

Without going into detail about this movie, I have to say I felt like this was the most pointless movie of my life. Not only was I to the point of depression for hours after viewing this movie, but I felt lost and wondering why people raved over it. Movies should be triumphing. Even if it's a sad movie.. The viewer (at least) should gain something by the time the credits roll. I gained nothing but sorrow, confusion, and dead brain cells after watching this. It's not the acting. It's not the filming. Everything was actually pretty good! The story was pointless and illogical. I lost 2 hours worth of time (again because I gained nothing new) and I wanted to slit my wrists afterwards... It was that depressing!! I definitely don't understand how it won awards. It won worst movie I've ever seen, in my book. Not an easy award to get over here

reviews.review_title: A story of awakening. Not for young children
reviews.content: Not a story for young children, but an excellent one for teens and adults. Don't let anyone tell you about this story either. Let the scenes and the confusion of the central character absorb you. He is just young enough to accept the world around him for what he is told it is, but just independent enough to begin seeing its inconsistencies. If you are like me, you'll have an overwhelming urge to slap some sense into the sister, and have haunting questions about how do the events impact how they think.

reviews.review_title: A lot of potential, sadly it falls short
reviews.content: This movie was for me a major disappointment. The whole story of a German boy who is son of an SS commander, befriending a Jewish child in a concentration camp is great and would have potential to make a heart -and gut wrenching film akin to Schindler's List. Sadly I find the execution of the story to be sorely lacking. Firstly I would have preferred that the Germans spoke German, however I can, to some extent accept this as there has been good WW2 movies where the Germans spoke English. What really breaks it for me in this film, and what keeps me from being engaged in the story is the lack of character development, the lacking sense of fear in the concentration camps and the overall indifference to what happens to the characters. The only thing that makes this film watchable is the good performances of David Thewlis and Vera Farmiga. In the end I was left with a bitter taste in the mouth of how a great plot was so purely executed and I can't help but wonder of what could have been.

Young Bruno is forced to move with his family, and leave all his friends and the happy life he knew behind. His father is the commandant of a concentration camp near his knew home, and what Bruno thinks is simply a "farm". Bruno forms an unlikely friendship with Shmuel a child of the camp on the other side of the fence. This film had such a visceral effect on me emotionally that it took some time to get over it. In the end my whole body was racked with sobbing tears of true unimaginable sorrow and horror. I did not see the end coming at all, although I knew nothing good would come of Bruno crossing over into Shmuel's world. What the end result said to me was true humanity and human suffering knows no race, creed, or color. Cruel, incomprehensible death shown through the eyes of a child. Truly horrifying and chilling.
An act of disrespect to all those who are affected by the Holocaust.

I've read the book and absolutely loved it and this was a great film to portray such heartbreaking story...
The acting by Asa Butterfield was pure and just what I imagined from the character.
There's a lot of criticism which don't make this film any less of a great one.
There were some inaccuracies though which weren't bothering that much.
It's somehow painful to know everything Bruno doesn't. Wish we could see everything through the eyes of a child. So pure and innocent.
I loved the movie. The ending gets me every time and I can't stop crying even afterwards.
I recommend it strongly.

I've read some of the comments already posted here and every time the issue of whether or not the people in the movie should've spoken German, the answer is; no, because than the movie had to be subtitled.Now, I ask you, what is so wrong about subtitles? We all can read, right? This movie is even rated for older children, who can read. What's so wrong about reading?? And in the mean time you pick up a little bit of German.I truly believe that a movie with characters who portray Germans should be true to that language. Also the Jewish boy should speak his native language and not English. It even says in the book that they, at first, don't really understand each other.I have yet to see the movie, and if I still think its good regardless of the spoken language I will post this too.-----I have seen the movie yesterday and I can only add to my comment above that aside from the spoken language issue the movie still doesn't work in my opinion. Even though the story in essence could work, the many unbelievable things you see distract you too much to really get into the characters. I'm talking about (off course) fences with massive holes, a well fed-looking Jewish boy in a concentration camp and off course the 'sitting by the fence for hours unnoticed'part. In the book this works because your own imagination takes care of the pictures you see. In the movie it just totally falls apart.Good things (they also need to be mentioned): Asa Butterfield. He is absolutely brilliant! We can see what he feels, thinks and wants to do next by just looking in his eyes. Super!James Horner. The music is quite subtle for a emotional movie like this one. And that is exactly what works. I personally loved the music that played under the (SPOILER) gas chamber scene. I felt the air getting less and less and the fear getting bigger and bigger through the high sounds of the violins. Very, very well done! (SPOILER) The End. I was very happy that they didn't let the father (or anyone) find the body. That would've been horrible. I still prefer the ending of the book but I was happy about this little thing. All in all I give it a 6 out of 10. S-Thur

Beautiful storyline that made me cry. I lost my words for it, it truly touches your heart. Beautifully acted, opens your eyes concerning WW II, peoples' perception and motives/thought process and it is just breath takingly, beautifully acted and written.Thank you

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies of the year
reviews.content: Simply put, this movie was awful. The fact that viewers are expected to believe that the entire world speaks English is hard to overlook. But if you can get past that, you have to be a fan of poor acting, poor casting (who can't recognize Vera Farmiga from "The Departed" with a bad English accent), and poor make-up (the Jewish kid looks like your next-door neighbour, and a predictable story This is one instance in which I strongly disagree with critics. Don't waste your time on this one. I borrowed the DVD from the library so at least I didn't spend any money for it. I expected a touching story about victims of the Holocaust, but "The Pianist" remains the leader in that category.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies I have ever been subjected to.
reviews.content: If you want to know all about Nazi death squads, how they were just ordinary people, this movie is for you.If you want to know how hard it was for the families of the men who operated the death camps, this is the movie for you. If you want to avoid unpleasant situation, do not watch this movie.I still cannot figure out how anyone could consider this movie to be heartwarming. Is it like an Irving story, i.e.: they are all buried in the same grave?The acting is excellent, but it does not make up for the ugly subject matter and the gruesome ending.

......as a Jew who is very familiar with the facts surrounding the German massacre of my people in WW2, I am disappointed at some of the inaccuracies of this movie. Auschwitz had electrified barbed wire all around the camp and at no point could anyone have escaped in or out. Second, the children brought to the camp were murdered immediately unless they were murdered later. It would have been unlikely for any kids to be sitting around like Shmuel was. However, the premise of the film is fabulous and the end is very touching. It is so important for the world to continue to recognize the horrors perpetrated by Europe in WW2. And, I must say, while Europe and the rest of the world may see the USA as faulty and imperfect, greedy and racist, we NEVER perpetrated genocide on Jews like Europe did from the Spanish Inquisition to the Holocaust.

The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas didn't live up to the 7.9 rating that the IMDb community gave it. The story was about the son (Bruno) of an important Natzi soldier and his friendship with an imprisoned concentration cap victim (Shmuel). The movie starts in Berlin where Bruno has the essence of a child's life. He gets torn away from that by his father's job as an SS soldier. For a while he lives in solitude with his family. Bruno, the curious and adventuresome 8-year-old, would become friends with Shmuel who would change his life forever (Trying not to give the plot away).I said that this movie didn't live up to the 7.9 rating because of all the ridiculous nonsense that took place. Everyone that was in the movie had a British accent; they were supposed to be German. Many of the scenes were really stretched in order to make the movie 90 minutes (including credits). It seemed like there were minuets of people sitting at a kitchen table with awkward silence. Also, it seemed like there was no background on any character other than Bruno; both the father and mother didn't have names and there was no last name for the family. Next, everyone in the family is oblivious to Bruno's friendship. The mother doesn't question why he walks backwards with hands behind his back, the guards don't question why Shmuel consistently doesn't work, and the father doesn't question why Bruno wants to stay in an environment of solitude. It just doesn't make sense.Now, the movie wasn't all bad, just too much nonsense for me personally. -Dan (6.0 Stars)

reviews.review_title: Another Comment on the Spoken English
reviews.content: A stunning film, and as reported by some above, the audience at our screening was silent as the credits rolled. This was unusual for this audience (British Academy of Film and Television Arts, Los Angeles Chapter).My wife had a telling comment. She thought the only drawback (which I now see was hardly unique) to the film was that it was in flawless British English. I asked her why. Her two reasons: 1.) it would have been even more terrifying in German, e.g., hearing Deutschland Uber Alles in German would have been gut wrenching and 2.) it would have for sure won an Oscar as best foreign language film!On the other hand, as several other comments have pointed out, there is so much that is conveyed in this film with hardly any words, that one can overlook the use of English. My own reaction was that I was confused at first; I thought maybe this was a British family in Germany before the war. They seemed so likable, even "Father." Then, as the characters filled out and came to life, the evil ones seemed that much more evil, English or not.

This may contain a spoiler, not sure how that is judged.I'm guessing that the reason this movie appealed to so many people is, it has shock value. Pretty much what is common in all media nowadays, a cheap, lazy way to get a product out to market that sells (if it bleeds, it leads). Basically, the whole movie is built up around setting up the shock of the ending. So many common since things are slightly twisted to make the ending work. Sure, on the surface it works, but after adding up all the things that have to be stretched to make the ending work, the shock of the ending is just that, shock. No substance.This movie, when compared to good to excellent movies about WWII, is highly over rated. Making me really start to question what drives peoples minds, what has caused society to sway towards the "Jerry Springer" mentality.

Riviting. Raw. Barrier Braking.I have never seen a movie theater so stunned. So quiet. Nobody dared to move; as the final scene played out and the screen faded to black. The credits rolled but people still didn't move. Stunnded and speechless we all shuffled out one by one with the same look on every face.This movie will not leave your mind for a long long time.Words really can't describe every emotion or how this movie leaves you feeling. You need to see it. It will change you forever. Humanity it self is seen in a different light.

I'm furious and disgusted. This movie is repulsive. I can't believe so many people thought it would be a great idea to tell a Holocaust story from the perspective of a Nazi general's family. Abhorrent. I feel sick.

Look it takes a lot to make a man cry because we are not like women. Women can cry for no reason but men not so much. When I watched this movie I about balled my eyes out because it made me remember about the crulity of other people. It hurts me to see how people could be just underly cruel.This movie is by far an Oscar winning film. It is just emotional and touching the whole way through. I didn't see anything wrong with the movie I thought the acting was just fantastic and the layout of the movie was perfect. Wouldn't change a single thing about it. But I do recommend that kids under the age of like 12 should not watch this film without a parent because it would be to sad and cruel because at the end people are seen leading into a gas chamber with the two little kids. We know that they were all gonna die. Not trying to give out any spoilers but I'm just letting the parent know that this could be a hard film, even as an adult, to watch it but other then that great film.

I'm amazed that I can find nothing but praise for this film on this board! It was incredibly well made, yes, and up until the end I thought it was one I would really like. It was touching, effective, and seemed sweet and (as much as possible with Holocaust themes) family-themed and appropriate. But the ending was one of the most horrible I have ever seen and made it so I would never, ever recommend this film to anyone! Without giving any distinct spoilers, let me just say that we all watched in horror as the worst imaginable thing happened. And then there was nothing to justify it. If we had seen remorse on the part of the father, and been given the impression that maybe this horror touching him personally would be a life-changer and lead him to rethink what he was doing at the camp, the ending might have been somewhat justified. If we had seen a similar revelation in the sister, who was starting to associate with the Nazi ideology, that, too, would have helped.Instead, we see the mother sobbing wretchedly, completely broken -- but then, she was already horrified at what was going on and didn't need to be taught a lesson. And we see the father frantically searching for Bruno, but we have no idea of his emotions when he realizes what happened. Will he rethink his life? Or will he fit this into his existing mindset, blaming the Jews for what happened, and using it as a reason to kill more and more of them? There was no conclusion; nothing was wrapped up at the end. Viewers are left with a sense of horror, nausea and depression. There was little warning of this, as the rest of the movie was really good and the previews didn't warn of the atrocity in store. The DVD cover touts the fact that this was by the same studio as "La Vita e Bella" (Life is Beautiful), which is misleading to a fault, as the two cannot be compared--La Vita e Bella was tragic, too, but it ended on a hopeful note instead of total depression.So what was the point of this movie? What was the message? That the Holocaust was horrible? Yeah, I'm pretty sure we all knew that already.There's enough to be depressed about in this world right now; I don't think we need our souls completely driven into the ground. Unless you enjoy horrors or being completely depressed, I wouldn't recommend "The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas" to anyone!

Conveyed the horrible attributes of the holocaust way better than any of the movies or assignmentS we have done/watched in my history class. Also made 2 out of the five people in my home cry. I like the way it touches even the coldest of hearts by using an actual "German" boy. I found it shocking when Bruno lies about giving shmuel the food. Then I thought about it,and I'm reasonably sure I would do the same. I also found the propaganda about what the labour camps were interesting. Lastly I thought that this movie was very suspenseful but definitely not a pleasure film. This movie does the exact opposite of What you think may happen. This is the reason why it conveys the message,that the holocaust was a disgusting thing, so well. Very well done!

Well actually, the movie was great. It made me shiver and cry. And thats exactly what it should do. What a horrible thing we did, and still do each and every day. Not in the way of killing people by stuffing em in a gas-chamber, but the way most chickens find their way to our plate isn't much different. And the way Nazis thought of creating a better world isn't so much different than we do when spreading democracy and Christianity around the globe.Of course this is a terrible comparison, but just think about it for a minute or two. Freedom lies in the ability to choose, not within the power of a majority over a minority, which in principle is the same thing as what they did with the Jews. Thats also why i think it was a good idea to have all English speaking actors. It could have been us, it could have been you and me, instead of the Germans. We're no better when push comes to shove. Most of us would have probably done the same thing, for our nation, for our believes, or whatever bullshit reason we can conjure up.Lets hope that one day we'll understand the true nature of unconditional love.Namaste.

I remember when I first watched this movie. I never wanted to watch it, because I thought it was going to either A, in subtitles,(which I refuse to watch), because it makes my brain hurt. B, be something dumb,boring,and (wait for my apology please) meant for little kids under 4 to watch! I.. WAS.. COMPLETELY.. TAKEN.. ABACK.. I went to lay down and fall asleep to whatever was on TV,and this movie was on! I said to myself, whatever I'll be asleep soon. Within 15 mins. I was hooked. The cast was beyond brilliant. I know these stories have been told time and time again, but they never ever get less haunting or more horrifying. I cannot pick which scene is "favorite", because they all were astonishing. The little boys were fantastic! I don't know if this is a good thing or a bad thing, but my daughter and I love this movie. We watch this every single time it's on. I will say this, if I would've seen the poster for the movie, I probably would've never ever seen the movie. That would've definitely put me on the you should not watch that list!

To be honest, having read a review before I watched this film, I was a little disappointed. It is a film, just, but the story is spread very thinly to make it go the distance, which in my opinion it doesn't, quite, even though it's listed as 94 minutes. The acting and photography are excellent of course, as one would expect of a BBC collaboration, and the settings, limited though they are, appear accurate, but the prison camp and numbers of extras, both soldiers and prisoners, are way too small in size and few in number for such a project. In many ways this film reminds me of a stage play adapted for the screen; it's just so 'pocket sized'? I suppose worst of all is that I can say it wasn't entertaining, or that I'm unlikely to want to watch it again, but that has more to do with what it says rather than anything qualitative. And in truth I believe we have been bombarded with this same moralistic tale since the 1950's. And really I am wondering why, given the all too common occurrence with which this subject, in one guise or another, pock marks human history. And especially given that extermination, by one method or another, is still happening all around us today?

Its a highly emotional film and certainly not for the weak heart-ed. It is about the Holocaust fiction or not, people tend to argue. However, the real point is missed which the movie depicts so brilliantly that the world through the eyes of a child is all pure and good and he knows no evil. As we grow old, all is forgotten as we make perceptions and stop asking questions. There is no point in arguing the historical accuracy of the film because that is not the point. As a film, it is brilliantly directed and acted. It touches an extremely sensitive issue and by the end of it something in you will implode. A real life changing film. It teaches a very important lesson of history, text maybe exaggerated but again, the point is hatred in any form is vile. People with power have done all sorts of good and bad things. This movie shows a mirror to all on the life choices you are making.

I've cried during movies- of course.
This is one of the only movies in recent memory, I've ever sobbed in mental anguish after viewing.
The spectrum of humanity is painful on so many levels.
It graciously personifies the member of the nazi party in a way I've never quite seen in these types of movies. The purity of Bruno's perspective almost lifts the gravity of what these people have done. But it's that same pure innocence and inquisitiveness that brings it right back into frame.
of course there is the foreground of the appalling in barbaric time period but that's just framing.
Who are "they"?
Who are "we"?
And the innocence.... god help us.
I was torn apart, not wanting people to be in pain but the poetic irony was not lost on me.
Yes there are some mechanics in the movie that we're a little bit of a stretch but all and all it left me haunted and reflecting for an hour or so after.
The pacing and weight of the film were perfect and quite spell-bounding up until the end that is.

As a second generation immigrant Jewish girl, this film was a lot. But as shocking as it may seem I did not cry, I watched this after watching Schindlers list, and that film scared me, so this film wasn't as emotional, I love it still though, beautifully told

reviews.review_title: The worst movie of the year
reviews.content: Director Mark Herman was clearly off his game with the release of "The Boy In The Striped Pajamas". After falling in love with the amazing novel by John Bayne, we were awaiting the chance to see this masterpiece come to life on the big screen, but to our surprise the brutality, emotion and realism of the novel and the Holocaust were forgotten in the making of this production.Starting out on to the poorly re-created concentration camp, Bruno(Asa Butterfield) played an ignorant 8 year old looking for a new friend. He stumbled upon Shmuel(Jack Scanlon) a young Jewish boy separated by the Nazi soldiers. Throughout the film, their "friendship" seems to grow, while Bruno remains completely oblivious to the tragic events taking place around him. As the story deepens, the action was minimal, and the whole story seemed built up around Bruno's boredom, and his mother's(Vera Famiga) fight to go back home with Bruno and his sister Gretel(Amber Beathe).Only to add to the disappointment of this movie, certain characters were poorly cast (Germans with English accent). Bruno's supposed terrifying father/commandant(David Thewlis) was nothing more than your average caring father. one would presume, and the novel certainly portrays that a Nazi commandant would be far more intimidating and aggressive. On the other hand, the cast was well chosen when they decided to portray Bruno's mother. Ther emotion and despair during this movie, especially when she learns of the purpose of the camp, was a breath of fresh air compared to others. Lieutement Kotler(Rupert Friend) and the poor Jewish cook Pavel(David Hayman) definitely brought a new feeling to the movie especially in the dinner scene.For such an intriguing storyline, the movie could have been made into a much more interesting experience for the general movie viewer. For a PG-13 movie, it was locking the details behind the Holocaust and the pain and suffering that the Jewish prisoners went through. All the elements from the novel that created such an amazing story were left in the pages of the book and not portrayed on screen. The setting, which was supposed to resemble a gruesome concentration camp similar to Aushwitz, was nothing more than your typical farm, which leaves the viewer emotionless to the realities of the Holocaust. Apart from the setting being poorly constructed, the bond between Bruno and Shmuel was looking almost entirely as the two boys were rarely seen together, which again disappoints the audience and disconnects them from the impact the film intended to create.Over all, 3 stars is the most we could give this film. The lack of emotions, gruesome details, the terrible setting, and rather disappointing acting, combine to make this film quite dull and unappealing. Potentially, audience members who have not had the privilege of reading John Bayne's novel, may enjoy the film. However, the farm like setting and unmoving character development is enough to even detract these viewers. The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas was better left on pages.
Touching, poignant and inspiring. It is one of the best films I've ever seen. Although it deals with children, everyone should see this.

This movie is bad. It is not bad because there is e.g. bad acting, cinematography, music or any other "ingredient" of good movie. Furthermore, the movie is very emotional, which typically should be good. But it is emotional for wrong reasons. As several movies of past two decades (The Reader, Der Untergagng to name a few) it attempts to turn culprits into victims or as some critics would say "it attempts to show human side of monsters". And this is simply wrong. At some point the movie manipulates you to feel sorry for regular war criminals. My problem with this film is that it seems to be a purpose of the movie - to feel sorry for war criminals, while their crimes are just like every day business. And this is why I gave it one star only. Someone may say this movie is about crime and punishment, but I didn't see it this way.
Two boys strike up an unlikely friendship and decide to have a sleepover.

"boy in striped pajamas"The Boy in the Striped Pajamas is a 2008 film directed by Mark Herman and based on the novel of the same name by John Boyne. A very powerful film that will not leave you indifferent, will make you think about a lot. The young actors did a great job with their roles, played well. I believe. The truth is too unambiguous characters, versatility is not grasped. Taking into account the points of view, the film has many errors, the work can only be regarded as artistic. Beautiful picture, angles and light, thanks to the operator.

Just picked this movie nearly at random from a boring night with DSTV in Africa and after first ten minutes started to look around again. Found nothing else so stuck with it. Was alone at home watching with increasing enthrallment as the characters and story evolved. The acting was brilliant and the plot increasingly compelling but nothing, absolutely nothing, prepared me for the ending. As the end came and the outcome increasingly clear i was transfixed, hand over mouth, unable to move. I sat that way for 10 minutes after the titles had finished. Having never even heard of the movie but seen others on the same subject i was absolutely shocked by the brilliant way in which the story unfolded to its terrible end. I am not normally a weeper but even now i still have tears in my eyes........ nothing more to say

reviews.review_title: This movie isn't any ordinary historical film
reviews.content: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas This movie is great it caught my attention from the beginning. I thought it was well played out if I would to have the opportunity to change something about it I wouldn't because it has a good story behind it. This is like a historical film that takes you back to the time when the holocaust took place the whole plot is set around that time but it's not any typically historical film that's going to bore you.Bruno is the main character in this movie he's 9 yrs. old growing up during world war 2 in Berlin, his family then gets relocated to a place where he thinks its named "out-with" but it's truly Auschwitz were his father is in charge of that prison camp. You're going to fall in love with Bruno he's such an innocent little boy he doesn't know of any harm in the world he thinks everyone has the great life he does. As time goes by Bruno gets bored of being in his house because he is not permitted to leave under any circumstances but he gets curious of why he can't play with the children he sees outside his window in "out-with" all wearing the same striped pajamas he then realizes that there's men of all ages wearing the same pajamas. One day Bruno sneaks out to "out-with" were he finds a little boy his age named Shmuel they become friends but he wonders why the little boy with the pajamas can't go out of the fence. A year passes by and Bruno ends up getting lice that was the end for his mother she can't take being in that place anymore and so decides to leave. Before leaving Bruno and his friend decide to have a last exploration day.The last exploration day for Bruno and his friend Shmuel is the best part of the movie I would say it's the most shocking part so that's why I'm not going to say what happens in this part because I really recommend for you to watch this movie, you should go rent it it's going to be worth it.

Very powerful, must see movie.From Wikipedia: On June 23, 1944, the Nazis permitted the visit by the Red Cross in order to dispel rumors about the extermination camps. The commission included E. Juel-Henningsen, the head physician at the Danish Ministry of Health, and Franz Hvass, the top civil servant at the Danish Foreign Ministry. Dr. Paul Eppstein was instructed by the SS to appear in the role of the mayor of Theresienstadt.To minimize the appearance of overcrowding in Theresienstadt, the Nazis deported many Jews to Auschwitz. Also deported in these actions were most of the Czechoslovakian workers assigned to 'Operation Embellishment.' They also erected fake shops and cafés to imply that the Jews lived in relative comfort. The Danes whom the Red Cross visited lived in freshly painted rooms, not more than three in a room. The guests enjoyed the performance of a children's opera, Brundibar, which was written by inmate Hans Krása.The hoax against the Red Cross was so successful for the Nazis that they went on to make a propaganda film at Theresienstadt.

The Boy in the Striped Pajamas ,explores the range of human emotions with the simplicity of an eight year old child. Set in the Holocaust period,Bruno is the son of LT commander in-charge of a concentration camp.left alone in a country side he befriends a Jew boy across the fence of the Concentration camp. He doesn't understand that this friendship is forbidden.Neither does he understand if his father was doing the right thing.Yet he wants to be proud of his father.The scene where he had to let his friend down is heartbreaking,the guilt of an 8 year old perfectly depicted by Bruno. When he wants to make up for it by helping Schmule find his papa,you are relieved to see that humanity has not died in the darkest age. When the movie ended it left me with a hole inside not because of the sad climax but the fact that what a 8 year old child could see and understand ,those adults couldn't.The message is inherent and no philosophical analysis is needed.What you need to do the right thing is to think like a child. Growing up is a trap,truly.

The movie is so stunningly brilliant that it will leave you grinding your teeth. A German family moves out of town and into a mansion in countryside adjacent to a concentration camp. The head of the family happens to be the chief supervisor of the concentration camp. His son is curious and he goes exploring the property.While exploring the area around his house, the German boy finds the way to the concentration camp. The German boy finds a friend in a Jewish boy in the concentration camp who later can't find his Dad. The German boy wears the garb of the concentration camp and together they go looking for the missing parent of the Jewish boy. Just how both the boys get trapped and walk into the gas chamber is the nail biting end of the movie.

"Childhood is measured out by sounds and smells and sights, before the dark hour of reason grows." -John Betjeman.Based off the bestselling novel by John Boyne, "The Boy in The Striped Pajamas" takes place in Germany during the horrifying times of World War II. We're introduced to the film with a clever quote (seen above) from the English poet John Betjeman; one that roots itself well with the perspective of the movie's lead character, Bruno. The story centers around Bruno (Asa Butterfield), his mother Elsa (Vera Farmiga) and eldest sister Gretel (Amber Beattie) who have recently relocated to the countryside of Berlin due to his father, who stays nameless (David Thewlis), gaining a hefty promotion within the ranks of the SS. Almost from the get-go we learn that Father's promotion is that of leading officer to a nearby, small scale, concentration camp. Bruno manages to sneak off periodically to visit a young boy named Shmuel (Jack Scanlon), eventually befriending him.Let's get some of the really negative points out of the way first. Something that bothered me from the very beginning is that the film's entirely based in Germany but all the actors are British and do nothing to hide their accents. To some it may be a minute detail but if you're trying to become emotionally involved with the story and characters it's very difficult when you keep hearing English accents, yet your brain is consistently reminded "This is based in Germany. This is based in Germany." Another film that became heavily burdened with this break in consistency is "Valkyrie". Time and time again it's shown that if you're going to have your movie based in a country where there are distinct accents or languages, you need to have your actors imitate those traits.Alongside the lack of consistency with the character's accents there's also a lack of consistency with the character development. The writing isn't terrible by a long shot but it doesn't get you as involved emotionally as you should, considering the topic of the movie. I understood what the director was going for; trying to get the audience to see the film in the way that Bruno saw every day life, through the eyes of a child and without reason being a form of bias. The issue here is the movie almost seems to take this a step too far and decides to completely tear away any sort of in-depth character development. It's like they want you to view it in the way that Bruno would but at the same time there's all these other adult themed, unfinished side stories that start popping up and things just get a bit bouncy.It's quite obvious throughout the film that the creators wanted you to care heavily for these characters and what happened to them but the flow of attention between each character became so wishy-washy that you didn't really feel connected to anyone. I have to say that while watching the entire film I really did feel like they were banking on the audience taking their already instilled emotions of the Holocaust and connecting them with the film as to avoid any emotional development. It's a tactic that doesn't sit right with me. You cannot take a well known, tragic event and simply use past knowledge of the tragedy to bubble up emotions. The story needs to be told as though nobody knew such a tragedy was a part of history.Overall I struggled a lot with this movie because one of the aspects that I really enjoyed also heavily weighed down the storytelling. I'm referring to the unique way of the movie trying to emotionally capture a film through the eyes of a child. The film itself can also be beautiful to watch at times. It's well scored and there's some really attractive cinematography that highlights the beauty of Berlin, regardless of the sad note the movie plays on. At the same time nothing really jumps out and grabs a hold of you at any point. The acting isn't anything to get ecstatic over, though I did really enjoy the performance from Vera Farmiga's character. Something just felt like it was missing from beginning to finish. Even the extremely devastating ending didn't warrant a single tear from me because the ride up until this point was emotionally bland. It's one of those films that I watch and become convinced that the only reason there's any serious hype over it is due to fans of the book or because it's a Holocaust movie and that gains a lot of sympathy points. reviews.review_title: A pointless movie and a waste of time.
reviews.content: Don't waste your time with this movie. If you want to see a good movie about the Holocaust, watch Schindler's List. If you want to watch something for any other reason, pick just about anything else.The DVD box cover blurb speaks of an inspiring movie about hope. Whoever came up with that never watched the movie. So to spare readers from a wasted hour and a half, here is the plot, if you simply must know.Boy #1's SS Nazi father is assigned to run a death camp in Germany during WWII. We know his father is evil because he smokes and never hugs anyone. Boy #1 is bored with his new house and his new tutor (whose curriculum consists entirely of 'Thou shalt hate Jews') and wanders off until he finds Boy #2 sitting inside the 'farm' fence. They manage to strike up a friendship without detection despite the Nazi guards that are omnipresent in the rest of the camp and around the commandant's house. Likewise, Boy #1's mother can't keep tabs on her son despite having zero social life or responsibilities. (Just why she doesn't run screaming off into the blue from boredom by the end of the movie is beyond me).Boy #1 generally eats or loses the food that Boy #2 keeps asking him to bring, but Boy #2 is pretty hard up for friends so they hang out together anyway (as well as they can with an electric barbed wire fence between them). Pathetically naive dialogue is supposed to endear viewers. It doesn't.Boy #2 is brought to the commandants' house to help prepare for a party, whereupon Boy #1 urges him to stuff his face with the goodies set out. When the Handsome Young Nazi officer catches them, Boy #2 bravely wimps out and says he doesn't know Boy #1 and had just walked in on the scene himself. (Handsome Young Nazi is soon shipped off to the Russian front for not telling anyone his father left for Switzerland four years ago. This, along with Boy #1's mother crying and carrying on when she discovers why those chimneys on the horizon stink so bad, helps show how _stressful_ it is being a Nazi flunkie.) Boy #2 survives his beating and nods when Boy #1 mumbles an empty 'sorry' afterwards. If you're looking for the hope and inspiration at this point, well, so am I. Boy #2 subsequently reports his father is missing (RIP, clueless kiddies), but Boy #1 has bigger news: his mother is taking him away to live elsewhere. He doesn't want to go (playing checkers with Boy #2 being such a thrill and all), so he grabs a shovel and digs his way under the death camp fence to help Boy #1 find his dad. In broad daylight.Boy #1 and Boy #2 wander the death camp until they enter Boy #2's lodging just in time to be rounded up for the gas chambers. Meanwhile Boy #1's family is turning the house inside out looking for him, eventually following his trail to the fence. Too late. Nazi father screams, mother hears and cries. The end.Did you miss the hope and inspiration? I did too. This was an atheistic movie without a point. About the closest thing to a spiritual angle is when Boy #1's sister says a prayer on the train ride from Berlin and mother smiles. But that empty expression of Christian faith is painlessly and easily replaced by her energetic embrace of Nazi propaganda from the new tutor (complete with bedroom walls adorned with SS posters). The Bible says "faith without works" is dead, and that is accurately reflected in this movie. No one (including the collaborating Jewish inmates) lifts a finger to oppose the Nazi agenda, unless you count Mom's wailing "I don't wanna live here anymore" when she learns why the 'farm' smoke smells funny.The Bible warns us to be grounded in our faith and not be blown about by every wind of doctrine. Confidence in his salvation and the rewards of Heaven gave Romanian pastor Richard Wurmbrand the courage and motivation to share the Gospel and demonstrate love to Nazi and Communist persecutors through years of hellish imprisonment and torture. The example of Wurmbrand and others like him stands in marked contrast to the futile gestures of movies like this one, which offer no reason why a person ought to be good or courageous or hopeful. Let's hope and pray the producers of this movie find real hope and inspiration in Jesus Christ.

reviews.review_title: Interesting Point of View  From a Nazi
reviews.content: Here's the thing with Holocaust movies. If you produce the movie from the perspective of a Jewish person, then the viewers will understand the real pain caused in World War II. The problem with 'The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas' was that the perspective was from the son of a high ranking Nazi commander, so it was harder to have sympathy for when the son was killed. I understand the point that they were trying to make about how immune the Nazi's became to killing the Jews and how when the commander's son escaped and was gassed, no one noticed. In a Holocaust movie, it is important to touch on a few things: the point of view from the Jews, why Nazi's hated them, and times when Jews received outside help from others. I mostly just got a gist of Nazi's and the life of high ranking Nazi commandant.The two best movies about the Holocaust that I have seen are "Schindler's List" and "Defiance".
